Mørk malt , brunt skum , sur øl ,rød flamsk, surlig sur , blød , medium skum, dejlig drikkelig.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhoneEarlier Rating: 5/24/2010 Total Score: 4.8raisin, port wine, grape, red, brown, cloudy, tan foam, heavily sour, vinegar, medium body, dry, lively, long finish,

Bottled:Pours dark reddish brown. No head or carbonation. Sour aroma of cherries, raspberries, blueberries, oak casks and glue with raisins in the background. Tart flavour of cherry stones, raspberries and oak casks with sweet raisins in the background. Long after taste. Very intriguing.
Hazy red brown colour. Low carbonation. Very complex aroma of sour fruit, raisins and oak barrels. Nice sour taste with some sweet hints. One of the best beers i ever drank. Very very good.

December 24, 2013 - bottle via trade that has been buried in my cellar for a while. Dark brown pour with no head, just a few bubbles. Sour cherry and wood in the aroma. Taste was consistent with aroma, but there was some malty sweetness as well. The wood dominates the taste, which I liked, and this had a nice clean finish. Medium bodied with very little carbonation. Lost Abbey label and 2008 vintage.

Poured from a bottle (pretty sure it was a Lost Abbey bottle) in a tasting glass. Pours deep ruby/brown with a small head. Aroma of sourness/tartness, dark fruits, caramel and toffee maltiness, and light oak. Flavor the same with a great blend of the components. Average texture. A good sour.

Bottle: Thanks Soren: Vintage 2009: Served in a Chouffe glass: Label says 11% ABV.
No head. Murky dark purple brown colored beer.
Nose of lots of red fruit with some tartness from berries, light vinous, (cinnamon ish) wood and a strong overall tartness.
Flavours of red fruit, sour, vinous, sour fruit, wood, light spice tones as pepper, cinnamon and something light clove ish. Good tart and nice red fruit cherry tones.
Aftertaste is tart with cherries, yeast, some malts, some vinous and woody tones.
Low carbo, tart creamy than watery mouthfeel, full body and a creamy texture.
Wow, 11%ABV and so easy drinkable with an incredible tartness fruit tone and balanced flavour overall. Amazing.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
Most recent release: 2010 Blend (I believe)

A: after requiring a crab claw to grip this bitch of a cork and pull out, I finally pop this one only to find the beer does not even toot out the tip of this cork. So I pour it, then it lands in the glass, rolls around and simply sits. No bubbles. No head. I can get a nice reddish brown color when light comes through. 

S: Cherries, oak, hint of vanilla, tannic and inky nose. Tart. Sometimes smells like laser ink toner.

T: Very woody, very cherry, very oak. Tannic at the finish. Hints of bitter manure flavor on the back end as well. Quite sour I guess I should mention. Some hints of plum as the beer warms a bit.

M: There is a hint of carbonation here. Pretty warm as well from the alcohol. Thick slick on the finish after my body restores from the dryness initially.

O: Well, its sour. Its low in carbonation. Its hot. Its got potential. Just not my bag. Still pretty pathetic for carbonation, but at least its not infected (per se).

Serving type: bottle

08-10-2011

Bottled. 
Red-brown colour with no foam. Vanilla and red wine up front, with root cellar and chocolate. Medium bodied with oily texture. Great beer in smaller doses.

Bottle - Lost Abbey.
APPEARANCE: brown/red beer, no foam.
NOSE: red fruits, wood, sour.
TASTE: sour, fruity, amazing!
Almost perfect Sour Red/Brown beer for me!

Bottle, as Lost Abbey. Brown murky. Very intensively flavoured and complex nose. Sour cherries, raspberries, some oak, aceto vinegar, dark balsamico to name few of the things popping up. Really nice. Body is slightly acidic, tart, dry, cleansing with a mouthwatering finish. Damp cola, some burnt candi in addition to the old, aged, fruityness. Overall very tasty, with the abv well hidden. Awesome drink, gets better with each sip.

2012 Bottle to snifter
Cherries, raspberries, bourbon, and oak.
Deep red, no head; it looks like a red wine.
Sour lemon, apple, cherry, oak...lots of oak. Strange, but alluring...an oaken sour.

Bottle - Vintage 2012 - Sour cherries, bit of funk and a lot of oak. Cloudy maroon and no head. Oak and cherry sourness, slightly acidic and sweet. The oak and cherries are in very good balance without the sweetness or sourness getting away. Very nice, but not for the price.

Riktigt mörkt röd-brun med bara lite bubblor på kanten av glaset. Doft: Kola, Cola, lätt rostat socker, söta körsbär, humle, "vin", söt malt. Smak: Trä, vinäger, färska och torkade körsbär, Cola, malt, humle, rödavinbär, kanderat socker, muscovado socker. God öl som blir ännu bättre när man tar andra glaset, alkoholen farligt dold.
Pours mahogany brown. Aroma is cherries, raisins, muscovado sugar, bourbon, figs. Taste is cherries, bourbon, figs, raisins. Aftertaste is bourbon and sea salt.

Sample from Lost Abbey bottle @sbwf13. Dark murky ruby brown with no head. Aroma of cherry, tart, black currant, plums, oak, fruit and slight alcohol. Taste has massive cherry notes, wood, alcohol, high acidity, vinous, cherry skins, cherry skins with a lingering, acidic finish. Wonderful

Köpt på SB. Riktigt mörkt brun öl med inslag av rött. Ett mycket lätt skum som försvinner snabbt. En del har haft problem med flaskor utan kolsyra, så var dock inte fallet med denna. En underbar doft av syrliga körsbär, jäst frukt, trä, vanilj, och en lagom mängd funkighet. Samma i smaken tillsammans med en mild vinägersyra. Ölen döljer sina 11,5% mycket väl.

12.7oz bottle, shared by DanielCoor. 2012 vintage. Labeled Lost Abbey. Murky brown red color. Dark. No head or lace. Just a couple bubbles. Awesome dark fruit aroma. Lots of great, tannic vinous qualities. Some chocolate in the flavor. Bigger body. Smooth, crisp kind of chewy texture. Lightly slick. Good, big sour taste. Light sweet. Awesome sour brown ale, very tasty stuff. Some chocolate notes.

Lost Abbey bottle, no date, looks new. Pours a dark murky brownish red with no head whatsoever. Aroma if black cherry, some tart cherry, plums, oak, hint of vinegar, slight booze. Flavor is big black cherry up front, some booze, tart cherry skins, dry oak, lingering dry tart cherry. No carbonation in this, medium heavy mouthfeel. Some heat lingering in the back of the throat. Very interesting beer. I like it but the flatness and the ugly look are hurting the score a bit.

Luckily acquired from ØlButikken. Pours scary, dusty, dark brown. Not much of a head. Smells sour with vanilla, bourbon and cherries. Taste has got licorice, cherries, vanilla, vinegar and bourbon. Very vinous and powerful. Lots of citrus/grapefruit. Makes you sweat, but really a crazy big sour!

@ Basunen: fin doft av frukt och fat. Stor syrlighet och en tydlig hetta men även en hel del bär. Lang och sträv eftersmak. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Urge as part of their Black Sabbath Lost Abbey SDBW event. Pours a dark mahogany brown with a one finger tan head with pretty nice lacing. Aroma is of sour fruits (mainly cherries), barnyard funk/wet hay, bourbon, vinegar, and some woody oak notes. Taste is similar to to the aroma but has even more bourbon and oak notes. Has a medium body with a semi creamy mouthfeel and a dry, medium long finish. Overall, a amazing sour brown that is a work of art.

Deep copper, clear, thin beige head. Aroma of toasty malt, tart cherries, dark fruit. Flavor of tart cherries, toasty dark bread crusts, some vanilla, acidity in finish b

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Ar: lots of lovely bourbon, vanilla, toffee, oak, tart cherries, fat maltbase, lots of alcohol, this one has it all! 
Ap: deep Brown/ruby colour, no head.
T: heavily sour, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, big heavy, boozy, lots of bourbon, big beer, lots of cherries, would have liked even more tartness.
P: fullbodied, soft almost flat carbonation, tart and warming finish.
O: solid!

Láhev 355 ml. Lost Abbey varianta. Aroma červeného vína snoubené s dubovými silicemi a alkoholem. Pěna je nahnědlé barvy, nulová a ihned mizící. Barva samotného piva je temně hnědá a silně kalná. Chuť je ve středu silně znát po kyselkách, okraje mají nádech oříků. Celková chuť je silně kyselá a to předevím fini který vrcholí v opravdu silném nárazu kyselosti který drí poměrně dlouho. Vcelku se jedná o velmi zajímavé pití, jeho kyselost je moná a příli silná ale za to mu propůjčuje osobitý ráz a unikátnost, vskutku originální počin.

Thanks a bunch to Niels and Rasmus for this unexpected tick Yeah BUUUDYyy
Pours murky dark brown, with a somewhat clear hue, and no head at all. 
Aroma is pretty darn complex, with all the sour notes up front, followed by a lot of bourbon notes.
Sour Cherries, brett, oak, balsamic vinegar, slight leather up front, followed by slight vanilla, slight banana. 
Theres really a lot going on, and this shit really is complex and unique. 
The taste is epic-sour, but is very well balanced by some vanilla/bourbon sweetness. 
Medium body, with an oily texture, with virtually no carbonation at all. Great stuff indeed.

38cl, Vintage 2012, at 11%Vol, as The Lost Abbey Cuvée de Tomme, exclusive American brew, with sour cherries, from Geers Oostakker, very complex sour fruit brew, sour/vinous and slightly woody/spicy, yet not too heavy, very balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Rated on 01-09-2009 at Fort Wayne, IN Winter Gathering (Bottle) This beer pours a small tan head that fully diminished, brown body, spotty amounts of lacing, and no visible carbonation. The Aroma is brett, sour and cherries. The Taste mimics the Aroma. The Palate is tingly and this beer is medium-full bodied. This beer is a bit too sour for my liking. This beer is worth trying if you enjoy this particular beer style.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2013 Murky brown, no head but tiny bubbles when I swirl the glass. HUGE aroma of vinegar,berries, raisins, wood, booz, cask, bourbon but overall more on the dried fruit vs berries side. Palate is superior. Full bodied, very sour and acidic. Sour finish with hints of raisins and heat. Extremely complex. Although it is obvious that this is oak aged, it is very subtle. Alcahol is not obvious considering the high abv. The full body does not effect the drinkability off this, this is truly magnificent.

Nose is mind blowing. Heavy malts, load of cherries, oaky, raisins, vanilla. Awesome well balanced and complex brew. Bit sweet with intense sourness, thou.. not too pushy. Price/performance.. not everyday beer, thou.. must have tasted

Bottle with SlackerMads, vintage 2012B. Pours hazy auburn with no head. Aroma is almost dense vinegar, intense sour cherries, plenty of acetone, generous amounts of oak, raisin, almond, coconut and bourbon. Taste is moderate sweet, light+ bitter and moderate+ sour/tart. Body is medium, texture is thick, carbonation is flat. Finish is very long, tart, warming and dry with raisin, cherry and vinegar. Incredibly intense beer - rather low drinkability.

A: Dark Brown/Reddish Hue, Passes No Light, No Head, No Lacing

S: Tart Cherries, Bourbon, Mild Oak

T: Tart Cherries, Red Plum, Mild Bourbon

M: Medicore Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Bitter, Mildly Fruity

Overall, a really nice sour mellowed out by the bourbon barreling, solid.

Botella. Presencia rojiza oscura sin corona y sin carbónico. Aroma a frutos rojos, café, levaduras y cava. En boca compleja con notas que van desde el café y frutos secos a vinos espumosos acidez equilibrada. Muy buena

Bottle, vintage 2012. Pours flat dark raisin brown with no head. Sour cherries, acetone, oak, spicy, bourbon coconut, raisins, figs, cheese, warming alcohol, red wine vinous. Long lasting light dry and sour. Medium body, medium sweet and sour, oily texture, near flat carbonation, light dry finish. Great slow drinking beer that takes a lot of focus. Im sharing this beer with pentaz who is yapping away and I cant pay attention. Probably makes no sense anyway.

Pours flat coca cola brown
Aromas of bretta, vanilla, cherries, oak, alcohol
Taste is warming of alcohol with sour grapes, cherries and red fruits. Also has a nice maltyness from the darker malts. Complex but very nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

very low carbonation and no head, dark red brownish. Aroma is insane, lot of sweet oak, tannin, vanilla and some dried fruits. Flavor quite different, very tart, yet very complex, red wine like character, some oak, cherries and finishes very tart. Extremely good beer.
Sample at SBWF 2013. Sweet and sour smell with berries. Similar taste but very powerfull. A very nice beer and nice to sip at.
Poured very cold. Reddish brown. Very low carbonation. No head. Aroma like red wine & cherries. Vinous taste. Cherries. Som sweetnes. Very acidic. Quite uniqe.
Tung doft av rödvinsfat. Fet syra. Lagom vinös. Dela en flarra på fem pers är nog lagom. Helt seriöst. SBWF 2013

Bottle 375ml @ Haakonm Pours dark brown with a few off-white bubbles. Aroma has notes of malt, tart, alcohol, dried fruits, vinegar and hint of soy. Taste is light sweet and medium to heavy sour with a long dry and very sour finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is flat.
Bottle - Dark brown in colour. Vinous and fruity aroma. Tangy, tart and fruity taste with vinous fruit, leather, cherries and caramel. Very rich and one to sip slowly.

Pours murky brown with no carbonation. Aroma is raisin, vinegar, wet wood and dark cherry. Taste has cherry, raisin, vinegar, oak tannin and lemon acidity. No carbonation whatsoever. My girlfriend called it cuvee-de-bleh, but I really like it!

A - pours murky deep cola brown with zero head. No carb from the bottle at all. S - very much a sour brown. Initial aromas are acetic. The musty wet oak, sour cherries, brown sugar, raisins, caramel, vanilla, dates. M - tart up front, to a dry musty sweet end. Full bodied, nice strong palate. Rich and full. T - follows the nose well. This is a great sour brown. Tart acetic acid, vinegar, and lemon juice roll quickly to a strong musty wet oak and funk. Palate is vanilla, raisins, brown sugar, and dates. End is sweet sticky and dry. O - A very mellow, sweet sour brown. 3.9

Bottle shared by Ryan, thanks man, poured an amber red with aromas of wet oak, light vanilla, tart cherries, and some light vanilla. Flavors are the same, tart cherries, and chewy wet wood, decent beer over all, thanks again man for the share.

Brownish mahogany with reddish tints... Aroma of cappuccino, oak, acidity... Flavor is coffee, sour cherries, caramel, oak, vanilla... Intensely tart, yet complex... Oak and brown sugar on the palate.... Amazing

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at Beer Temple. Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma of tart cherries, oak, barnyard, slightly vinous, raisins. Flavour is over moderate acidic and light moderate sweet. Full bodied with soft carbonation. An excellent American take on an old Belgian style, comparable to Struise Earthmonk.

2012 Lost abbey bottle, thanks to Chris for sharing for this! Pours murky red brown, with virtually no head. Smell is fantastic, tart cherries, oak, funk, sour..yum. Taste is tart cherries up front, lots of oak, a very smooth and dry finish, with almost zero carbonation. Lots going on here and not just a sour bomb. Loved it.

2011 Bottle. Dark red pour. Like a bag of blood donation. Aroma of sour cherries. Taste is really tart. Not much semi sweet, cherry, redwine, bit of booze. More tart than sour. This is like belgian red on sterroids. Tasty stuff but definately a sipper.

2009 vintage at Green Lion, Malmö. Pours mahogany brown. Aroma is cherries, raisins, muscovado sugar, bourbon, figs. Taste is cherries, bourbon, figs, raisins. Aftertaste is bourbon and sea salt. Fantastic!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375ml at my place with Taylor, Thomas, Scott, and Erin. Aroma of fig and leather with a touch of sourness. Taste of heavy currents, rich oak Chardonnay barrel. Finished medium to long rough medium finish. Medium mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to Peter! 2013 vintage. Pours a cloudy brown with no head at all. Aroma of dark fruit, wood, and malt. Taste is tart cherries, tart plums, oak, malt, bourbon, and a small bit of vinegar. Truly amazing!

Bottle through trade, muddy brown pour with no head. Aroma of rich sweet caramel and bourbon, taste of bourbon and a big tart funk in the back, bit of a hot finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Holy smokes, amazing sour beer on tap at beechwood brewety , lots of cherries, dark barrel aged sour yum!
Another great sour beer that I enjoyed at Nodding Head on June 2 during Philly Beer Week. 3rd best beer we had out of the 16 we tried that day.
2008 375ml bottle pours a dark black/brown with zero carbonation. Cherry oak aromas. Tart Cherry vanilla and red wine taste.

750ml bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor: I have been in search of this beer since hearing of it about four years ago. Never had any luck finding a bottle when asking employees at Pizza Port, but it has finally been made available for us humble seekers of beer. Upon pour, there is no foaming or any sign of an attempt for the formation of a head to develop which lead to the thought that this was not a good sign. Once poured, I noticed an instant olfaction of dark juicy fruits such as berries and cherries, but until I stuck my nose into the glass, it wasnt till then did I begin to pay attention to the raisin and wild use of yeast further. The flavor is initially a tart and sour taste that also stretches across the taste buds to allow for a moment of sweetness that will only be a glance of the fruits potential. Obvious mentions of fruit are dark black cherries freshly picked yet unripe and sour. Also, gives me a memory of eating a basket of washed raspberries that have recently been rinsed and they are juicy themselves but with the added beads of water to the flesh of the fruit just makes it that much more juicer and refreshing. Somehow the raisin gets drowned out and takes deep thought to recognize in the faint background of the aftertaste. The yeast has an interesting personality of its own because of the wild funky almost farmhouse like style of yeast present. I now understand why someone could believe this is Belgian strong ale, but in my opinion this falls under a fruit lambic style. Very enjoyable and smooth in its palate that comes across so gently carbonated all for which makes for an easily guzzled liquid.

2012 bottle. Dark brown-orange, flavor and oily. Nose of vinegar, cherry, chocolate. Flavors of chocolate, cherry, yogurt, nice sour cherries. Smooth and completely (too) flat. Nice but did not live up to its reputation by any stretch. Alcohol well hidden, though it really misses the carbonation.

375 Bottle - 2012 vintage. Pours totally cloudy brown with a vanishingly small head that disappears rapidly leaving no lacing. Aroma is tart cherry, wood, caramel, dried fruits. Flavor is bracingly tart with light sweetness. Cherry and wood are the dominant characteristics. Dries out by the middle, leaving TART, woody notes and a groundswell of heat from the ABV. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, but flat as a board. Interesting beer, but there is certainly nothing subtle about it. And why the fuck cant Lost Abbey keep carbonation in their beers???

Tap at NoddingHead for beer week.  Aroma of plums, cherry cola, sour oak, and slight vegetable (celery).  Telltale signed of spoilage.  Pours hazy purple and completely flat.  Taste is upsettingly sweet with brandy, plums, spoiled oak, and black cherry soda.  Way too intense a taste to be that off in flavor.  I may have gotten a bad batch but I think this is overrated.
Bottle. Pours brown with a thin head. Funky woody and sweet malts, cherry fruits, hints of bourbon, and a light hit of acidity. Balanced and drinkable. Really damn good.

On tap. Pours brown with absolutely no head. Still carbonated though. Complex aroma. Cherries, oak, vinegar, and even a little bit nuttiness. Served a little too cold. Flavor is tart cherry, oak, and a little alcohol. Never been my style but this tolerable if not somewhat enjoyable.

2009 Vintage thanks to spacecoyote ! Pours a deep ruby brown color with a finger of khaki foam. The nose is very complex... sour cherry, cola, cranberry, welches grape juice, wet funky wood, vinous cabernet notes. The palate follows the nose with great complexity and deep dark vinous notes. Nice chocolate malt backbone, great acidity, cranberry, cherry, bourbon.... really nice. Great lingering finish... YUM !
(Critique chaotique du extreme beer fest 2013): Assez agressif sur le palais, foncé en bouche avec des notes de fruits, cuir, brett. Échantillon trop bref pour apprécier sa complexité.

Bottle 37.5cl 2009 vintage thanks Allen. A red amber beer with low head. Nose is on sour cherries, vinegar and vinous. Aroma is on wood, cherry, acid, sour and vinegar like, lactic, alcohol well hidden. Bit disappointed not as impressive as expected.

Pours Reddish brown with thin tan head. Nose of sweet spice and yeast. Nice dried cherry sour taste with some malt for some great balance. I am not a sour fan and this is impressive. Might convert me into a believer!

2013 Vintage - On tap at Original Gravity in San Jose. Pours murky brown with red hues coming through with bubbles escaping on top and around the sides of the glass. Awesome aromas of tart cherries, funk, brett, barrel, leather, raisins, wine and bourbon. Flavor is pretty much the same with additional dark fruit interwoven with the tart cherries. First few sips are rather sour, but the mouth gets used to it and unlocks some other interesting complexities. Finishes pretty dry with oak after tastes. Pretty awesome sour.
All I can say is "HOLY CRAP!" This beer is da bomb. The color of motor oil. Zero head. Amazing aroma of raisins. So many flavors, its hard to identify. Slightly acidic.

900th rating! 2009 375mL bottle pours a murky muddy brown with no head. Aroma has lots of cherries, vinegar, caramel, tootsie roll, and sour apple skins. Taste of sour cherries, apple skins, caramel malt, and finishing with bitter leather lacto notes, and some pepper. Very balanced but not a huge fan of the finish.

Bottle 375ml.
Almost no "pop" at opening. Pours dirty, murky dark brown. No head to speak of. Aroma is of vinegar, fruits, malt, sourness. Taste is of malt, sweet, caramel, fruits, sourness. Palate: Medium body. Overall: Very sweet, sour too. Multi-layered. This one is quite disapointing for me. Its a mess. Maybe there is a reason why "no other beverage in the world tastes like this". Well, some seem to like this. Gonna leave future bottles to those.

Bottle (375 ml). Traded by Whatsarezaf, thanks Reza! Ugly murky brown with no head and no lacing. Aroma of red fruits, chocolate, caramel and slight acetic notes. Taste is moderately to heavy sweet with red fruits, chocolate, oak, vanilla, caramel, moderate sourness and acetic notes. Low carbonation. Not bad, but not really impressive either.

0.375l corked bottle from 2009. A treat! This is a lovely looking plush-plum-red one, no head what so ever. Lovely vinegar-like aroma with apples, paint thinner, balsamic, peppery spices, caramel, grapes, wood and soft yellow raisins with red stolen fruits. Really interesting and quite complex. Its really concentrated and just lovely on the flavor! Sticky boiled down green apples, something almost sea-like salty, red wine vinegar, wood, sour dry grapes, black pepper, and it has a lovely slightly stingy finish and aftertaste that tickles your throat on so many levels. An amazing flavorful and exciting beer! 26.12.2012

375 ml bottle, 11.0%.
Pours dark murky red color with a minimal head. Aroma is quite "winey" with bourbon notes, lots of ripe dark berries, bilberries mostly, red wine, some wood, yeast, . Flavor of ripe fruits, dark berries, some yeast, mild subtle red wine, almost port-like tangy notes, wood, mild vanilla and some grassy notes. Very complex brew with a lot of nice nyances. Top notch.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2013 
37,5 cl bottle (11,0%) @ olio as The Lost Abbey Cuvee de Tomme. Thanks tiong!
Very quickly disappearing, big‐bubbled head. Aroma has rum, raisins, whisky notes and red wine. Flavour is rather tart with red wine, some bourbon, woody notes and hints of raisins on some sips. Like a good red wine in the beer world. Very intensive and good, really slow beer like Angels Share.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2016 375 ml bottle. 11% ABV. Thanks tiong.
Pours a dark, dirty brown colour without a head. Aroma of strong sour berries, cherries and dark chocolate. Very rich flavour of strong sour berries, bread, dark cherries, dark chocolate, bourbon, tannin and strong wood. Full bodied, oily and rich mouthfeel and strong, sour, vinous and woody finish with berries. Excellent, this is even better than RR Supplication. Top notch.

2012 vintage at 4 years of age. Pours a dark amber colour without a head. Aroma of red currant, some bread, a bit of cherries and grass. Flavour of super strong red berries, lactic acid, wood and bourbon. Full bodied. Super oily, smooth and warming. Bloody great.

375ml bottle from a trade, thanks stawn!

Pours dark reddish brown with no head. Strong aroma of raisin, dark ripe fruits, tart berries, hints of oak and wood. Taste is complex, heavy and vinous with a lot of dark ripe fruits, tart berries, vanilla, oak, sour cherries and smooth wooden notes. Finish is long lasting, sweetish and malty with a lot of tart berries, smooth bourbon, vanilla, oak and wood. Vinous and complex, but extremely well balanced and tasty sour ale. Excellent beer.
Draft at Monks. Pours a hazy purplish brown with no head. Aroma of cherries, lemon, vinegar, grapes, dark dried fruits, some spice - perhaps nutmeg.  Pretty tart finish.

deep coppery amber pour, with little to no foam. small film of tan foam. sour flemish-red notes. some woody oak and red berries.  taste is sour, also like a flemish rot, rather bitter but also very fruity. very good, and almost no alcohol is evident. medium body and low carbonation.

Pours a muddy dark brown with no head. Aroma of raisins, cherries and bourbon.  Taste is cherries, bourbon figs and cherries. Nice tartness, solid sour. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, shared with Bergen Beer Geek Tasting Crew on Christmas Tasting 2012. Been waiting for this for a while, but its Christmas and were breaking out the big ones! ;-) Pours a clear deep brown body with a ruby hue and a tiny white head. Aroma is mild acetic malty tones, wood, caramel, hints of straw and lactic acids. Nice. Taste is dark fruits, lactic acid, tart wooden caramel tones, hints of cherries and straw. Mellow body, soft carbonation, and the alcohol - ridiculously high if compared to the Belgian archetypes - is amazingly well masked. A truly well-balanced and tasty sour in the Rodenbach/Flanders red tradition.

On tap at Brouwers Café for Big Wood 12, pours a dark, dirty amber brown with a small beige head. Aroma of light vinegar, complex oak barrels and some sour fruits  uber complex. Flavour is insanely complex with loads of oak barrel complexity, varied soured fruits, just the right amount of vinegar  oh man. Sours have never been my thing, but damn, this is insanely complex and highly drinkable. Finishes oaky, vinegary and barely sour. I had to go back for another full glass and still craved more. Phenomenal stuff  as of this review, this is the best sour Ive had.

On draft at Bigwood 12/6/2012, from notes [3 of 11].
Appearance:  Beautiful deep ruby brown.  Small ring of off-white head.
Aroma:  Dark fruit.  Bourbon.  Vanilla.  This will be good.  
Taste:  Mmm.  Bourbon barrel sweet oak vanilla.  Love it.  Sweet with a ?? of tart [wow my handwriting is atrocious].  The tart finish blends perfectly with the sweet start, and the two harmonize beautifully.
Palate:  Moderate carb, good coating mouthfeel.
Overall: <3.  Everything I love about deep, dark, sweet barrel-aged beers (e.g., Sucaba) married to the sours I also love.  Top notch.

Refrigerated 12.7 oz. bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours chestnut brown with very little head.  Little lacing, medium body, low carbonation, and slightly musty aroma.  Taste is raisin, some cherry, and hint of bourbon. Complex but expected more.

Poured from a 375 ml bottle. Pours a flat, murky brown. Aroma is musty, tart, cherry and raisins. Smells like old wood. Taste has more going on than the aroma. The cherries and raisins come through better in the taste. Thankfully the Bourbon isnt that strong.

Bottle from 2008 received in trade. Thanks Eric.

This is a great beer. Nice complexity elegant taste and a wonderfull sourness. The best american sour ive had so far.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2013 Deep reddish brown color. Opened this bottle with no "pop" and hence had no real head to speak of. Just a faint level of carbonation detectable. Regardless, the aroma was super funky and vinous. Lots of juicy merlot notes but with some barnyard funk and a hint of sweetness, and oh yeah, VINEGAR. Flavors were deep and rich like a red wine, perhaps seeming more so because of the lack of carbonation. Very rich and compex smoky, cocoa, dried cherry flavors. Mouth-wateringly sour. Maybe a hint of alcohol as well, and a bit of oaky woody bitterness. Pretty intense, very complex and interesting. I will have to try another to see if its more well-carnonated.  Does it kinda sound like I enjoyed this?  Because I didnt.  It sucked.  I poured it down the drain.  I felt ROBBED!!  Ill never buy this again.  Ill only accept it if someone gives it to me for free (ahemmm, LOST ABBEY, I feel as if they kinda owe me one?  Cause it was $17 for 375ml).  The word "cuvee" conjures up thoughts that this will be among the finest offerings from the brewery, but OH LORD HELP ME, it is among the worst Ive tried from Lost Abbey.  They should have made salad dressing out of this.

2010. Ugly as sin: muddy brown body, zero head or lace. A double paper bagger. Heavy oak character through and through. Pretty sour, darkish fruits and funky yeast on the palate. Bitterness from the yeast is apparent, though the sourness lingers. Much better aged than fresh.

3 nov 2012, tap. Cloudy brown. Nose has both sour vinegar and wet yeasty bread. Thin body and moderately fizzy. Vinaigrette up front and quickly turns sourdough bread dough and chocolate malt. Delicious. Reminds me of duchesse de bogornia but not as vinaigrette. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very tannic aroma, dark fruit, cherries,  raisins.  Dark brown almost black. No head. This is a 2009 vintage by the way. Really ominous looking. Taste is super mouth watering sour. Some fruit some wood, but a really sour beer. 
Raisins evident, tannic as shit.

Sampled at a tasting.  A cool looking beer in an ancient way.  Big cherries, yeast, funk, and malts are smelled.  Cherry flavor leads with berries and more fruit.  Spice and sweet malts.  Truly unique, tasty, and interesting.

Sampled at SBWF11
Murky amber. Almost no head.
Really sour in both aroma and flavour. Vinegar with sourness and some sweet notes.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2013 2009 vintage. Wow, totally unique, for sure! Pours a reddish brown with small tan head. Aroma is dominated by red and black berries, mostly cherries. Theres some yeast and a touch of bourbon as well, and some barnyard / hay. Taste is what makes it so special. Rather than a fresh, fruity sourness, it opens with a thick barrel cask sweetness, almost like a sherry. Then the cherries kick in, and the sourness picks up, but never to become dominant. Finish is long with alcohol, cask and cherries. Body is light to medium. Fairly low carbonation.

Edit: Tried the 2013 vintage, and its still pretty much the same, lots of berries and some barrel aromas, followed by a very fruit and barrel rich taste which isnt as sour as you might expect. However, very balanced, and the barrel tones does help the overall character of the beer.
2009 bottle from Marcus has a dark brown red color. Aroma is sour with a hint of fruit. Taste is nice a mouth puckering sour.great beer

bottle, from brewery. good aroma, tart, sour. Cherry, red berry, yeasty funk. Cloudy, reddish brown color, small head that quickly faded, no lace. Sour flavor. lite body, smooth mouthfeel, tart sour finish. Mmmm, darn tasty, aroma and flavor realy pack punch. only weakness is appearence, imo. darn tasty
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Muddy brown with no head or sign of carbonation. Aroma is sour cherries, caramel, raisins, hint of chocolate anc a touch of funk. Velvety mouthfeel, perfect balance of sweet and sour, very complex. Taste is cherry, chocolate, raisins, brown sugar, red currants. Like a liquid black forest cake. Simply amazing.

The beer pour a murky dirty brown with no head. The nose is  warm spices, red fruit and a hint of funky musk. The pallet is quit complex with a bit of funk, raisin, sour cherry and finishes with a mellow oak and bourbon flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

CdT is a great beer, the warmer it becomes the more complex it becomes. I drank half of it at room temperature which in Florida is warm! Cherries & fruit are very prominent, not much carbonation, which is not a problem for me. Definately a sour to try.

Bottle, 375ml corked. As Lost Abbey Cuvee de Tomme. Its an almost clear one, brown in color and topped by a minimal sized light beige head. The aroma has vinegar, dark berries, a hint of candy and some faint caramel notes. Quite complex, layering up pretty neatly. The same can be said about the flavor, where theres also a faint licorice hint, some chocolate and a hint of black pepper. Full body, hiding the alcohol warmth very well. Lasting finish. A wonderful beer, with the aromas and flavors well integrated, making it a very balanced beer. Would certainly not shy away from having it again. 120302

A-- Poured a deep, murky brown color. First thought was that this is one ugly looking beer. Except for a couple of bubbles this had no carbonation. No lacing, no nothing. 

S-- Sour cherry, slight bourbon, vanilla, wood, plum, raisin and very wine like. 

T-- Even more wine like I thought. Chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, wood, and slight amounts of cherry. Reminded me more of a solid shiraz than a wild ale really. 

M-- Sour cherry finish. Front and mid were more the bourbon and vanilla. Once again very wine like to me. Slick and long lasting flavor. Little to no carbonation to this but with that much complexity it really did not need it. Alcohol was minimal at best. 

O-- Ugly looking beer but very good. Not the big bright flavors or sour vinegar that other sours have. Really good beer and really enjoyable.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2012 375mL courtesy of Shane. Thanks! 2012 vintage.

A: Murky brown with no lacing. This is completely flat. Damn.

N: Cherries and bourbon. Vanilla and caramel. The sourness rises just above the cherries. And there are a lot of cherries here. Marionberry and prune. The smell is quite pleasant.

T: Muddy. Lots of sour cherries mixed with an overpowering sweetness of caramel and bitter chocolate. I admittedly cringed a bit. Ive had this before, and it s not nearly as weird, I swear. There is so much cherry here, and it might be the saving grace. If this beer had one. Vinegar and acetone. Honey in a way thats like a mead.

M: Slick and oily and sharp. Not good.

O: I really dont understand what happened here. Last time I got a bottle of this (a 750mL) this was sublime. Tart and sharp and perfect. This is an unmitigated disaster. And I have one more. With any luck, this will taste good in 2014. And if it seems Im being overly harsh, its because I know how good this beer can be
Cloudy reddish almost brown pour with a nice tart cherry aroma and the flavor is similar with some brett is noticeable.  its just flat out awesome!!!
Bottle. Red dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is alcohol, malt, berries, wood. flavour is alcohol, malt, berries, red current, cherries, brett. Full body. Very nice beer.

Shared at a small tasting at my place last weekend.

A: Mahogany brown with a pretty small, timid head that doesnt linger.

S & T: The aroma and taste are quite similar. I found them both to be extremely complex with aromas and flavors consisting of cherries, wild yeast, oak, vanilla, malt, misc. spices, bourbon, alcohol. Theres definitely a lot going on here. While its noticeable that the base beer is a quad, Cuvee de Tomme has become an entirely different beast now. The souring and barrel aging have taken over and now dominate the flavor of the beer. That being said, this is a well done, artfully crafted beer that I find intriguing and enjoyable.

M: The feel is medium bodied with sour notes throughout - not the type of sour that makes you pucker, but rather a consistent funky cherry and wild yeast flavor that blends in cohesively among a barrage of scents and flavors.

D: Quite tasty and profound. This is a great treat to share several ways. Recommended.

I was concerned about this beer as I had heard of widespread problems with carbonation. 

This beer was a pleasant surprise! Lightly carbonated (but not flat like I had read) and very refreshing. The bourbon barrels really tie this slightly sour ale together. Very nicely done!

Bottle of 2011 vintage. Pours a muddy rusted brown water looking color with no head, only a few bubbles. The aroma is very vinous, with lots of tart cherries and dark fruits, I get some funk too, caramel, toffee, spice, raisins and vanilla. The flavor is sour, but not insanely sour, and is almost dead flat, making it drink like a wine. I get some tart cherries, dark fruits, raisins, toffee, caramel, brown sugar, spice, vanilla, oak and funk. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a tasty brew, but it needed more carbonation.

Shared at a Lost Abbey sour tasting. Thanks to Tomme Arthur for bringing this one. Poured a slightly muddy red color with not much of a head. This brew was great - plenty of tart notes, sweet malts, cherry and some bottle notes. Hey there Brett, nice to meet you too. Very tasty and nice.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar. 2009 vintage. Clear, deep red/brown liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of sour apples, funk, oak, vanilla, cherries and dark fruit. Taste is light sweet and light to medium sour with notes of dark fruit, cherreis and almonds. Full bodied with soft carbonation and sticky mouthfeel. Really enjoyed this one! Wonderfully complex.

New vintage bottle to oversized snifter (thanks darkmoon66). Looks like an opaque old ale; no carbonation whatsoever with razor-thin lacing. Smells fruity and boozy. Tastes like it could be infected (or at least I hope so based on other reviews). Palate is butterscotch. Not impressed.

Sampled 2008, 2009, 2010 back to back to back all because of the wonderful generosity of John! unbelievable.

Rating is for 2008 edition, because well it was easily the best sour ive ever had.

2009 was more tart and acidic but would definitely get better with some time.. more cherry and wood note in this one

2010 way more tart bordering on unenjoyable, still an awesome beer but needed to be more balanced.

Pours the color of cola, but cloudy and with no head.  Looks flat.  Aromas of heave oak notes, wine, slight funk, sour fruit.  First sip reveals it to be completely flat.  The funny thing is, I had a hell of a time getting the cork out... Had to use a pair of pliers to pull the fucker out.  Vinous notes, slightly sour, slightly sweet on the tounge.  Another reminder that this is a completely flat beer, and I will deduct points for that.  This is going on your permanent record, Lost Abbey!!!  I wish this beer was a touch drier.  Taste is very nice, dark, heavy, sour... But just too much residual sugar.  Not worth $15 a bottle.

Tap at 3rd Annual Boulder SourFest (06-02-2012). Pour is deep, hazy, amber/brown with a small tan head. Bourbon, molasses, light cherry, char, alcohol, and raisins in the aroma. Taste is tart cherry, oak, funk, light bourbon, and moderately tart throughout. Palate is very creamy with medium carbonation. Overall this beer smells like a boozy stout, but the sourness in the taste really balances the bourbon out well. Absolutely no signs of alcohol in the flavor and I thoroughly enjoyed this one. Mmmmmmm.

Craft Brewers Conference 2012 
Golden in color, hazy with a thin white head. Big sour aroma and nice sour finish.  This is a great drink and taste like there is so much complex yeast and mixing going on.  Big barrel flavors and finish also.

Wow - toffee, chocolate, bourbon and amazing sour cherry/lemon and acidity.  What an amazing beer.  Especially for the strength.  The toffee lingers and nice acidic tartness.  Has to be one of the best.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2013 2010 vintage bottle at S&B - pours viscous dark brown - great leggs! aroma of soy sauce, apple and balsamic vinegar. Full blown start with with a huge palate overlay and a perfect sweet & sour balance. Taste of chocolate and cherries with a salty butterscotch finish. Spectacular!
----
Kept rating after having sampled a 2-year old vintage - shared with Urbain Coutteau. We concluded that the flavours remain very rich as well as the initial body but the vinegar sting in the throat is rather annoying.
A: fruity, winey. A: deep red. T: medium sourness, fruity. P: m-fb. O: 19/20. WOW

Pours a nce ruby color with very little tan head.  Aroma is musty and oaky with cherry...touch of chocolate and fig.  Flavor is sour cherry...ver sour...great musty oakiness.  Mouthfeel. Is medium/full with a dry, oaky/cherry sour finish.  Wow!

Btl  @Sour&Bitter 2008; Little head, coca cola colour. Super nose with raisins, prune - like an too old wine - in the good way. Medium and very long. Taste is raisins with plenty of red burned fruit: Berries, prune and even a light licorize. Really fine yet quite heavy.

Purchased this from a guy doing a cellar cleaning. 750ML format, 2009 Vintage. Stored in the cellar for a month or so. Poured into an Ommegang Glass.

A - Very small cork of the pop with very little carbonation. Tiny coffee coloured head but dissipated almost instantly. This beer is a very dark hazey brown. Looks closer to a the liquid you get following squashing grapes. On a glass swirl, more red dark cherry colors are apparent. 

S - Dark cherries dominate the nose followed by a very musty basement mold smell. Smells akin to a very old Bordeaux I had in France. Lots of wild grapes and bits of dark fruits and pineapples.

T - Holy moly! This is a total sour bomb. White wine characters of grapes and musty mold. The tartness is very similar to hand picked Muscadines.Nice sour cherries on the back of the tongue. The sour funk and wild characteristics are way more pronounced than expected which must be the age of the bottle. I dont have a 2012 vintage to compare it to. The vinegar notes are great as Im a huge fan of vinegar. Theres a minor hint of oak wood but its very subdued compared to the sour bomb that is this beer.

M - Minor carbonation on the mouth swish. Medium body. Huge sour funk that lingers for a very long time after drinking. 

O - I was not expecting this to be such an intense sour beer but Im excited that it is. Also, I hear now that the 750ml is a very rare format for this beer and the 2009 vintage. Stoked to have had both and bummed that, after opening I cant share this with out local tasting group.

350mL caged cork bottle shared by Someister. (thanks again!) Fairly dark brown w/ some reddish coloring & low carbonation. Lots of Brett, sour, bourbon & slight cherry aromas. Get more sourness & funk upfront, but loads of vanilla, oak & bourbon the rest of the way. Incredibly complex- each sip tasted different. Amazing!
Draft at Monks Cafe. Awesome aroma of chocolate-covered cherries, oak, and whiskey. Flavor of sour bourbon and cherries. A touch harsh on the sourness, but overall a really good beer.
Bottle shared by CptnSpeed1, thanks Brad. Poped with almost nothing behind it.   Murky redish brown pour. Tart cherries on the nose and in the tongue. Very nice!
Bottle, 2009. Pours red with an off white head. Smells nice, sour, fruit, interesting. Tastes balsamic, acetic, and quite so, but with some nice cherry

Bottle at Lost Abbey Tap Room. It pours cloudy deep amber, with a reddish tint and a thin, bubbly, off-white head. The nose is balsamic vinegar, strawberry, cherry, sweet red fruit and wood. The taste is malt vinegar, balsamic vinegar, tart cherry, raspberry, strawberry, wood, vanilla and a touch of alcohol warmth, with a tart-tangy finish. Medium body and low carbonation. Well balanced. Not overly complex, but very drinkable.

375ml bottle, labeled Lost Abbey Cuvée de Tomme, 2011 vintage I believe, received in trade with mikedashg. Thanks! Pours a murky, reddish-brown color with no real head to speak of. A few bubbles around the edges of the glass. Aroma is dark fruit, cherry, Oak, vanilla. Medium on the palate with little to no carbonation. Flavor is sour, fruity, cherry, wood, oak, vanilla, With a sour cherry finish. A very interesting and complex beer. I can imagine how good this is with bubbles.

At 2012 Avery Strong Ale Fest.  Murky chestnut brown with a foamy light tan head. Smells woody and slightly sour with some candied toffee. Slight sour palate with some acidic wood and earthy sweetness, slight tartness fruit. Weird, but its interesting and complex. Kinda tasty and sippable

375 ml bottle. Clear, seep amber body with a thin beige head. Aroma is caramel, malt, dry fruit, wood, Soya and quite vinous. Flavor is both sweet and sour, there is chocolate, dark malt, dry fruit, sourness, berries and caramel. Complex and quite big in flavor, still surprisingly easy to drink. Fantastic.

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Vintage 2009. Hazy reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, berries, alcohol and moderate sour - vinegar. Flavor is quite sweet, rather acidic and rather bitter. Dry, rather acidic and rather bitter finish. 270112

Tap @ Avery, doing the 10th Annual Boulder Strong Ale Festival. Pours hazy brown with a offwhite head. Aroma is sour winelike with malt, oak, cherries, vanilla, chocolate. Taste is sour cherries, malt, winelike, tart cherries, oaky, cinnamon, notes of chocolate. Thin to medium body, soft carbonation, lasting tart sour finish. Fantastic. 090312

Bottle at James Im-a-bro-again party. Thanks to whoever actually bought this. Pours dark red or brown with small head. Aromas of red fruit and vinegar. Great sour: sweet, fruity, vinous and sour without being overly tart/acidic and mouth-puckering. I usually like those last qualities very much, but this beer showed me that a sour doesnt have to go to that extreme to be awesome. "Balanced" sour, I guess. Mouthfeel is extremely light and I even used the word "vapory" at one point. This stuff evaporated up into my nasal cavity as I savored it on my tongue.

Pours like muddy dark brown. very little carbonation and quickly looks like a strange brown wine.  The aroma is far different than any other sour that I have had.  Notes of figs, raisins, and spice.  I also pick up a bit of a vanilla note from the wood, and a bit of basalmic vinegar. The flavor is tart with a sour cherry and other fruits, followed by a touch of that vanilla and raisiny flavor of judgement day.  The finish is nicely tart.  This feels like a good red wine in your mouth and going down your throat.  This is beverage is unique in flavor, appearance, and mouthfeel.  It is barely recognizable as beer, but was an awesome experience to drink.  I am happy to that I have another bottle to try in 6 months or a year.

Bottle, courtesy of yngwie. pours dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma of red berries, funk, wood, balsamic vinegar, licorice and malt. Flavor is sweet and sour with some chocolate,red berries, oak, malt, caramel and some tartness. Medium body, average carbonation .

This is an over the moon beer if you like things like sours and flemishes.  The soure cherries bring a whole need world to beer.  The flavors are as complex as the beers color, a deep brown almost purple hue.  The head quickly disperses, but the flavors linger on the tongue for a long while.  I am aging two of these.

Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012 - Day 1. 2009 Vintage. Brown color with a small beige head that quickly disappears. The aroma is lovely, sweet malty, raisins, oak, bourbon,sour cherries,  vinous, some brettiness. Taste is moderate sour, very rich vinous flavor, vanilla, ripe fruit, caramel, cherries, oak wood. Like a sour/Barley Wine hybrid. Easily the best Us sour of the night. Lovely stuf.
I could barely tell that this was 11% ABV. Still sour even without so much tart presence like other wild ales. Its very drinkable but pricey!

Thanks to AndrewNations for this bottle in the Secret Santa exchange. Boy, its been a long time since I had much from The Lost Abbey. 375 ML bottle, no hint of vintage, taken down while the wife is out at Drinking, I mean, Book Club.

Cork exits the bottle with nary a whimper. Silence. Poured into a nice tall glass, it exhibits as much carbonation as the muddy brown river water it mimics. Im sure Ive fished in this beer. Aroma is better, sweet & sour cherries, passing oak, alcohol. Smells & looks more like a wine than a beer.

Cuvee de Tomme give me the o-face. Ooooh, man. From the lack of carbonation, the heavy brutishness of the mouthfeel was to be expected, & it flaunts every tick of its 11% ABV. Three sips in & already wishing Id split this with someone. Severe is the word that comes to mind. Sour cherries form the wide base, along with hints wine & oak. Backdrop of rum, sour raisins, prunes.

Well, now Ive experienced Tomme & I have to say Im underwhelmed. Under carbonated, stone-heavy in the stomach, & not much depth underneath the blistering sourness of the cherries. Honestly, this feels like a home brew experiment gone haywire; hard to score, it has its moments, but ultimately, this cant be the intended outcome. I hope.

On tap at City Beer Store.  Pours a dark brown with a small tan head that settles to a ring and leaves some light lacing on the glass.  The aroma is vanilla, bourbon, hints of brown sugar, some light funkiness, a little leather, cherry, and hints of raisin.  The initial taste is quite tart with some lactic acid and a bit sweet with some brown sugar.    There is also bourbon and vanilla, and some cherries.  The finish is tart with some acetic acid and some lingering bourbon.  Full body.  Medium-low carbonation.  The alcohol isnt detectable, but you can tell it is a fairly big beer.  Quite enjoyable, but a little bit more sweetness than I like in my sours.

2009 VintageTasted in late November 2011 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle at unclejedis birthday tasting, big thanks, Jim.  Pours dark brown/red with a thin tan head that leaves a thin collar of lace.  The nose is malty with some caramel and bread, sour, funky cherry, and some vinous balsamic notes.  The flavor is tart and sour lemon pith, and balsamic vinegar, with the same funky cherry and caramel and bread malt from the nose.  The body is medium and tannic with light carbonation and a long balsamic cherry finish.

Reviewed back in 2009 - Cuvee pours a dark mahogany brown color.  When I popped the cork I got a nice little pop.  A lot louder then I got from Older.  A small amount of head and bubbles formed but quickly disappeared into what you see on the right.  The aroma on this beer is fantastic.  Dark fruit, sour cherries, oak, and a little bit of alcohol.  Its definitely a sour aroma but its not really big.  Not like some other beers Ive had like this.  Taste is just as good and I was left wanting more when I was done. Up front is a nice sourness/tartness.  Thats backed up by cherries, bourbon, and oak.  Its a great combo of cherries and smokey oak.   Alcohol definitely plays a role here.  It doesnt interfere with the great taste though.  The sourness sits on your palette and lips.  Mouthfeels lies more on the thick side.  No carbonation like I said and silky.  Goes down nice.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 375 ml bottle shared by jsprime. the most insanely intense sour dark ale ive ever had. beyond the point of trying to explain it. huge dark fruit and wood. deeply complex sipper. the best of all the big dark sours ales, great beer.

Bottle @ FOneFan. Hazy brown/dark amber/red with tiny beige head. Aroma is vinegar, malt, fruit and dried fruits. Flavour is malt, vinegar, vinous, little vanilla, dried fruits, brett, little acetone, little toffee, little tart and oak.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Small head with short duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are brett, caramel, nuts, fruits, wood and malt. Nice and sour. Great beer.

Tap @ Regal Beagle.  Showed up at this bar last week ordering from their quality selection when we noticed that everyone was ordering this one.  Im not particularly a fan of sours, in general, so this beer wasnt really on my radar until it became clear that everyone else had come just for this.  Thankfully I ordered one, because this beer was quite the find.

Pours dark brown, ruby in some light, creamy in another.  Aroma is sour cherries, bourbon, other dark fruits, caramel, wood.  Flavor is immediately sour, but with a nice warming from the booze.  As the drink warms, the sourness and sweetness create a very unique experience.  The cherries are always there, but are never in your face.  11.5% for sure, but the alcohol flavor is never really powerful.  Creamy and warm with a sour finish.  I will definitely be grabbing some bottles of this.
Sour cherries, bruised apples, raisins and funk blend together for a wonderful taste.  Damn near a perfect sour.

2011 Bottle.

Sweet cherry aroma, also a distinct Pinot noir aroma. Maybe some hints of brandy. No head to speak of, dark hazy mahogany. Bitter sour finish, but a nice subdued cherry flavor, the sour is apparent the entire time but it is not overwhelming. as the beer warms, it becomes more manageable,

Bottle, 2010 ed, courtesy GT2, thanks brosef! Pour is muddy ruby/brown with no head, some bubbles. Aroma of raspberry, oak, chocolate, fruity esters, funk. Taste is quite nice: subdued sourness, oak, chocolate, light vinegar, raspberry. Palate is soft, oily, lactic finish. Just outstanding.

Shared bottle with Timfoolery. Pours a brown color with a smell of tart/sour funk. The cherry flavor was the most overpowering. The total lack of carbonation always throws me off, but it was smooth on the palate. Very solid brew.

Bottle from my source... Aromas of tart cherries, wine barrel oak, and sour funk. Looks unspeakable without any carbonation or lacing. Flavor of sour, tart cherries and rather dry. Extremely well made. Some carbonation would help, but we didnt wait to age it. Excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured amber with zero head. Aroma of  tart cherry and barrel wood. Very acidic, with the low carbonation the sourness tends to linger pleasantly, with the sour cherry and wood continuing throughout.

2011 bottle (thank you, Kyle and Cara). Pours murky, reddish brown with absolutely no head. Nice sour aroma of wine, cherries with hints of vinegar and oak. A taste of sour cherries with a bit of raisin in the background. Slightly acidic with great brettanomyces tones. Nearly all the flavor hits early, then edges into a dry vinegar finish with a hint of butter. A great, complex beer despite the low carbonation.

2011  bottle.  Booze, oak and as it warms I feel there is a tiny hint of dark cherry in its aroma.The aroma is misleading to me when you first taste this beer. Meaning, I did not get much if any aroma of the cherry tartness that comes through in this beers taste. 
I find the appearance of this beer to be pretty. Murky, brown, slight hint of red, greatness in its glass. No head, no lacing. However the non-existence of the head does not necessarily take away from the enjoyment of this beer. Flat thought. 
There is a more upfront palate, not a lot of lingering to me personally. On the top of the palate there is a definite presence, however more like up front.  
It seems like there is somewhat of diacetyl I am experiencing way towards the end of the very minimal lingering of this beer. 
This beer has some definite flatness to it, however I am impressed on how much I like it. 
Cheers to our new good friend amtran87, thanks!!!!
Smells funky, sour cherries and oak. Pours with almost no carbonation and tastes different every sip. Being flat did not ultimately have a serious impact which is seriously good.

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. Aromas of sour cherries, oak and brett. Sour cherry flavor with some woodiness and brett funkiness. Quite acetic. Medium body with average carbonation. Thanks Craig!

Pours like blood with no head and no bubbles save for what air was caught in the glass. Aroma is vinegar, cherries, oak wood, very acidic. Taste is red fruits, sour cherries, red grapes, sour red apples, oak, and just a hint of vanilla. Interesting and (to my palate) unusual. I still dont quite have the hang of Sours, which may account for the score. Worth a shot; if you like sours, you may very well love this one.

murky reddish brown, with an almost non existent  off-white head, Aroma: Tart cherries, slight acetone, lacto acid, red berries, very fruity, sweet woody, acidic, loads of dried fruits, light dusty, overripe fruit,  light farty, some brett, but in a fruity way, almonds, rotten apples, sweet vinegar, has some flemish sour action going on. soft carbonation. Taste: lemon upfront, very acidic, tart cherries, some fruity bitterness, very dry, oak, dried fruits, sweet vinegar, sour red berries, some earthiness, light acetone, some brett, woody, red apples, but also sour green apples, very fruity and refreshing. the alcohol is extremely well hidden!

Lost Abbey Cuvee de Tomme - 2009. Bottle looks good. Beer in the glass dark brown, small head. Sourish-dry aroma. Starts intense sour, almost aggressiv. Fruity notes of berries in the background. Finish a bit less sour, more fruity, a bit earthy. Too intense for me.

Bottle at local tasting. Pours unclear dark amber with a small white head.Aroma is a lot, some chocolate, cherries,claret and vinegar. Taste is light sour cherries and brett, very tolerable and delicious sourness. Warm mouthfeel, dry. Complex and good.

Bottle, as The Lost Abbey Cuvée de Tomme, kindly shared by gunnar. Dark ruby colour, large beige head. Unusual and very complex aroma, oaky and vinous notes, sour cherries and farmhouse. Sour flavour but not extreme, the cherries are there but not totally dominant, also oaky notes.

Bottle (375 cl) from the Cracked Kettle. Hazy mahogny, almost no head. Fruity and caramelly aroma with the background, sour cherries up front with some notes of wood. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Dry with medium to high acidity.

Sampled at SBWF. Stockholm, September 29th, 2011. 

Musty aroma with notes of berries - Blackberries, cherries for the most parts. I also get a strong wood note. Very acidic and sharp aroma. The taste is incredibly sour and heavy. Slightly sticky with big cherry flavours. Warming alcohol in the taste as well.

Bottle thanks to Flecthfighters. Pours a murky brown with slight reddish tints down the side of the glass. Great nose of malt vinegar, sour cherries sweet dark fruits, acetone  and a little oak. Flavours show lots of wood, vanilla sour cherries and more malt vinegard. Good stuff.
Stockholm Beer & Whisky Festival 2011. Amber beer, small head. Sweet alcohol aroma, fruity, cherries, oaky notes. Sourish flavor, citrus, sour, grapefruit, rubber and hay, earthy notes.
Sampled at SB & WF 2011. Amber with a brown head. Smells sour and tastes sour and alcohole with a similar finish.

Lost abbey cuvee tomme. Sample @ SBWF 2011. Pours redish amber with a small off white head. Aroma is sour cherries sweet hoppy fruity. Flavor is fruity sweet sour pungent bitter. Finishes sour bitter peppery.

Sample @ SBWF on September 29. Pours reddish brown with a small white head. Smell is very complex with vinegar, cherries and dried tropical fruits. Taste is sour with notes of burnt sugar and sour cherries. Very complex taste with lots going on. A great sour beer.
dark redish brown with no head. Woody with acidic notes. Wood, sour, fruit and acid. Full body with long sour / acidic finish.

Pours a dark ruddy amber with absolutely no head formation at all.  In fact, theres not even the slightest semblance of a bubble in the beer anywhere.  Smells of sour cherries, earth, a bit of a funkiness to it, and a touch of vinegar as well.  On the palate the beer is as flat as a pancake...no carbination at all.  Dang it Tomme Arthur!  Go figure.  The flavor is still ok with a decent amount of sour cherries coming through, funky earthiness, and a bit of oak and wood as well.  Not bad, but it was flat.  Poo!

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor! Pours deep ruby reddish amber with a small quickly fading off white head. Aroma is heavy on the cherry, touches of plum and a touch funky, really a tiny bit of sharp vinous but mostly sweet and fruity. Flavor starts sweet and again heavy on the cherry, picking up touches of vinegar and a tiny bit of funk, but again, heavy on the cherry and dark fruits, which isnt really a bad thing. A bit of woodiness and red wine notes in the finish. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Pretty decent beer
Pours a murky brown and totally flat. Bready musty nose and taste. Did not enjoy this going down and the wild yeasts in it gave me a not so happy stomach.

NFL KICK OFF!!!! 375ml bottle Cuvee de Tomme. From Secret Santa. This poured a dark red to brown color with a very small head. Aroma was sour cherries, alcohol, brett, yeast and some funk. Flavor was just incredible tartness upfront, both from the cherries and the wild yeast, then some alcohol warmth, then a nice funky oaky bourbon finish. A world class beer indeed. Thanks Santa

Aroma: Cherry vinegar, oak, cherry, raisins.
Taste: Plum seed, cherry, oak, caramel, lemon, blackberry, raisins.
Mouthfeel: Sour, balanced, big body.
Notes: Dangerously balanced. Didnt realized that it was 11% after half of the bottle.

375 ml Lost Abbey bottle. Very psyched about this beer, a long time want. The appearance is a little discouraging as it looks like a disgusting puddle of swamp water. Murky brown, sediment, and absolutely no head. The aroma is nice though, sour cherries at first and then an explosion of cocoa. Winey grape like notes are also present. The taste is also quite good, cherry dark chocolate flavor with lots of vanilla/bourbon and light tannins. The beer is quite heavily bodied and completely flat. It definitely has the potential to be a world class beer if it could look and feel like one.

375ml bottle, 2008 from Toronado SD - thanks Ian for pulling this one out. brown with tan head. Sour, tart, vanilla, oak, light bourbon and funk, cherries and some plum. Mild palate but medium bodied, great carbonation, sweet yet tart, great finish that keeps on giving. A very interesting beer - cant believe how well the sour and bourbon work together. Highly worth seeking out a good bottle.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2012 Bottle @ home, courtesy of daknole. I really appreciate it, Dak! Deep purple/brown appearance with no head. Moderately sour, dark fruity, blackberry, plum, dark raspberry, cherry, tart aroma. Tart dark cherry/blackberry/plum fruity, moderately sour, slightly spicy, a bit sugary, slightly boozy, acetic flavor with a dry, vinous finish. Acidic, dark fruity aftertaste. Pretty strong but quite tasty brew.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2016 Bottled. Pours deep mahogany nearly black with virtually no head. Aroma  of of vanilla, wood, vinegar, funky notes and sour, dark over ripe cherries. Tart flavour with sour fruit, dark cherries, spices and notes of raisins. Medium bodied, creamy texture and flat carbonation. Ends up tart and with some alcohol. 🌟🌟🌟🌟

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 Pours darker brown with allmost no head. Aroma is dark sweet ripe fruits, oaky awesomeness, caramel, vanilla, light vinegar, sour berries, light funkyness and raisins. Taste is red wine, more sourness coming through, raisins, cherry, light bourbon, sweet dark fruits, caramel, vanilla, and some sour berries behind. Sick balance.. Very pleasant to try ..

2009 bottle.  Deep red pour with white foamy head.  Smell was dark rich cherry with vanilla sweetness and mild barnyard.  Taste was cherry tartness, oak, dark fruits, and cranberries.  Finish was mellow and then a spike in tartness with a slight bittering element.  Great wild.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2012 Like a super rodenbach. Starts very tart dips down into a dark fruit cherry raisin sour then one of the most complex finishes where the tartness ramps back up to heavy tartness then slowly fades away.

Bottle (from the november 2005 RB-tasting at Dixens place - notes have been damaged by flooding of my basement, but this was such an insane tasting for me as I was new to such massive tastings, so I gave up on the detailed notes quite early). Raisin, alcohol, heavy aroma. Sourness with a lack of fruitiness. Didnt like it then, but Im gonna try it again asap.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2014 Bottle.  Dark reddish/brown pour with no head.  Aromas of sour cherries, oak, and brett.  A little thin in the body, but well balanced with tart cherries, caramel malt, bitter stone fruits, and acidic citrus qualities.  Well done.....

Re-rate (2011 vintage on tap at Public House in La Jolla)  Huge caramel malt notes with luscious sour cherry, vanilla, and oak notes.  Delicious.  Moved original rating of 4.0 to current rating of 4.3.

2009 750ml bottle. Dark ruddy brown; thin tan head. Aroma - oak, bourbon, sour bugs, lots of oak, very sharp. Sharp flavor also, in the sourness. Not extremely sour, just very cutting, actually reminds me of some sharp cheddars. Lots of oak adding body. Hint of bourbon.
2009 bottle. Pours dark brown with little to no head. Aroma is sour cherries, bit of vinegar and alcohol. Flavor is all sour cherries with a hint of alcohol. Pretty good sour overall.

Again big thanks to Trappistlover for this one!

2010 Vintage poured into snifter.

A: Dark red with very very very little carb bibbles on the outer ring. I know this beer is said to always be flat so I expected such.

S: Really nice, acidic vinegar smell with some cherries and maybe a little spice in there. I dont smell any of the bourbon though. Smells a lot like a red wine actually.

T: Great, like the smell acidic, but really well blended with the other flavors. I definitely taste the cherries but I am also getting peach and sour apple, outstanding. The lack of carbonation isnt really bothering me.

M: Dry and flat, but truly not bad.

O: This beer far surpassed my expectations. I loved it. The carbonation wasnt a problem for me, however if there was a bit more this beer would definitely rank higher and be on a whole other level. Worth the hunt if youre into sours.

Appearance - Not much here, Its a bit murky and thin looking. The color is consistent with a normal quad but the way it moves in the glass gives me a idea that this one isnt vicious at all.

Smell- The smell is a bit sour with some slight Belgian notes of sweet sugar. Its a bit hard to separate the two on the nose alone but I get something unique each time I smell this one. Maybe some sour cherries and fig/raisin notes that come in and out.

Taste- My first impression was this is a great red wine. It really does have very similar notes as a good wine. Initially I thought this is a run of the mill quad spiked with brett and nothing more. I get all the great characteristics one desires in a Belgian quad. The sourness is dominant and doesnt leave a whole lot of room for anything else. This is apparent form the beginning to finish. Im planning on laying this one down for a year or so and seeing if the sourness fades. It may take a while..

Mouth- A bit thin and very little of any carbonation.
Drink- I dont get a lot of booze on this one despite the high abv but the sourness makes this hard to drink.

Serving type: bottle, 375ml

A very still pour. I kind of could tell when the cork was fighting me pulling it out. A very dark hue as well. Its not black, but pretty close to it. If I look at a shallow volume of it, it has a nice ruby brown color. More ruby than brown. A slight ring of bubbles clings to the edge of the glass where it is met by the beverage. A very smoky sourness is what I first get from a sniff. Somewhat acetic smelling. I can definitely tell there are raisins in this thing. I get the sweet molasses aroma of them. Almost like a maple syrup in there. There is also, after some time, a considerable alcohol presence in the nose. Smells okay. Wonder what it tastes like?

A very sour, oaky taste is immediately sensed. Leather. Raisins. Sweet molasses. A little tobacco. Very complex. The only hint of cherries seems to come in the back end. It is more like a sour cherry juice feeling as opposed to taste. And not really a mouth feel either. Its like a sweet and sour taste. But not overly cherry. It is very hard to describe. There is a sweet taste midway through each swallow. And a big alcohol warmth in the end. So it starts out sour and tart, then gets to a nice sweetness, followed by a slight warm, sour and sweet after taste. Nice complexity.

Bottle thanks to madirish76.  Aroma: sour cherries, earthy, oak, cocoa, red wine, ripe fruits and vanilla, somewhat sweet.  Pours a very dark, almost opaque muddy ruby color with no head, very low carbonation.  Flavor: very ripe, tart cherries, sweet caramel notes, lots of oak and vanilla, plums and raisins, bourbon, vinous, tart and puckering, dark sugars, actually pretty boozy in the finish.  Medium-full body, somewhat slick on the palate, puckering in the finish.
Thanks Dom for sharing this bottle. An absolutely unique and brilliant beer. The sour cherry, oak and brett work perfectly together. One of the best beers I have had!

375ml bottle, 2009. Dark brown pour, very murky. Aroma is super funky with hints of sour zest, raisins and cherries. Flavor is pretty much straight sour funk with hints of raisins and bourbon, pretty boozy as well. The ABV is 11% but drinks very smooth. One of the tastier sours Ive tried.

8/24/2009
375ml bottle 2009 Vintage
Given to me by Barleywinebrewer, thanks for the opportunity Bill!

Poured into a Maudite Tulip. Looks the color of coca cola, only no head. A few small bubbles cling to the surface but quickly disappear. Smells of raisins, cherries, vanilla, brown sugar, a touch of vinegar and alcohol. Taste is sour cherries, tart acidic flavor with some funk. Slight vanilla, vinegar and a touch of alcohol. Carbonation is almost non existent, mouthfeel is a sour syrupy mess, body is medium. I think I would have really enjoyed this one if it were carbonated, but as is Meh.

Mild kirschiger Antrunk, erfrischend, etwas holzig. Süffig, etwas holzig, wenig alkoholisch. Das Kirscharoma geht nach und nach unter, die leichte Säuerlichkeit bleibt aber nach wie vor vorhanden und passt sich dem weiteren Aromenverlauf an. Dieser ist noch würzig-holzig, mittel-malzig und etwas herb. Die Aromen wirken teils etwas gegensätzlich, im Gesamtbild passen sie aber dann meist doch recht gut. Nett, aber nicht super. Danke an DerDoppelbock für das Teilen! 10/11/11/10/10/11
Courtesy of Nate.  Pours brown with red hues, rimming brown head.  Cherry and sour, brown sugar, cherry, fig lemon.  Tastes of sour cherry, lemon, b rown sugar and caramel.  Just wow.  Great sour.

Share at DLD 11, Interesting tasting stuff, the bottle was a little flat, not much carbination. But the pour was kind of a murky pale ale. It had no head, Had nice sour notes come through. A little fruity almost. Good stuff

Bottle shared at Dark Lord Day. Thanks for the share. Poured dark brown with little head. A very thin body with little carbonation. Other than that this was fantastic. Very sour with little backbone. Well done.

The sour pours dark amber with barely a maroon hue. The aroma is warm cherry pie with some light sweet and sour notes that are pleasant. The flavor of warm cherry pie and tartness, almost no sweetness, on top of a perfect body, full for a sour. Really excellent as expected!

Vintage 2009, corked bottleVery dark brown color, almost black; medium-sized creamy head. Strong aroma, wild and vinous, with chocolate and malt, a bit sour; old wood. Good body strength, chocolate and malt flavor, with sour cherries fruitiness, balsamic vinegar, lactic acid; there is some residual sugar, but hidden; the sourness in the end is higher, quite aggressive, a bit astringent, tannic. Mouthwatering.Very complex. Bold but well balanced. Excellent.

A flat beer? From Flat Abbey? Whoda guessed it. Poured into a tulip.

2.0 A: Ruddy dark plum color. No head.

3.5 S: Bourbon and cherry are the main attraction and work really well together. Sourness from the cherries and the bugs and vanilla from the barrels. Tangy lactic acid fruitiness. I bet this would smell amazing if there was some carbonation to shuttle aroma molecules to the surface.

4.0 T: I bet it would be amazing if the easy part was done right for once. Usually when bourbon meets Belgian, the bourbon covers all the subtle Belgian flavors. Apparently when bourbon meets Belgian and that meets cherries and bugs, the result aint bad at all. Anyway, sour cherries and lactic acid start this off with a tangy sour punch. Leathery bourbon, vanilla, and oak supplement this well. Light "supple tannin" astringency. Vinous with prune and fig fruitiness.

2.0 M: Medium body. Flat, flat, flat, flat, and flat. Super smooth though.

3.5 D: Despite Tommes usual carbonation antics, this is actually pretty good. This would be one hell of a beer with carbonation. This has a lot of things done right, but one major thing done wrong. Shame on you Tomme for releasing your namesake with such a major flaw.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-05-2011 04:43:06

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 375 ml bottle shared by STLWill- thanks a ton, Will! Will was nice enough to hit a couple of my Wants in one night. Lost Abbey bottle, looks nothing like the pictures. Latest vintage. Pours a cloudy cola brown color with a small tan head. Aroma of toffee, butterscotch, berries, oaky funk, vanilla, and brown sugar. Flavor of berries, grapes, caramel malts, oak, toast, and vanilla. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a balanced mouthfeel of sweet and tart. Really nice, sweet, funky sour. Re-Rate; no new notes but an upgrade.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2012 2011: This is the second year that I have had this beer and just based off of my notes from last year, the cherry aroma seems to be slightly more subdued this batch. The appearance is identical to what I remember and the carbonation/lack of head still leave a bit on the table. The taste is wonderful, the front of the tongue seems to have changed a bit. With more bread or yeasty qualities before the mouthfeel is taken over by the slightly tart cherry flavor. I will lower the rating based on the fact hat this years batch is being tasted after having tasting about 150 or so new beers since I first tried this. This years batch receives a 3.6

2010: The aroma on this beer is of sour cherries, wine tannins, and some of the yeast coming through. The appearance is very interesting as it pour with little carbonation, only small bubbles around the side of the glass, but on the tongue with the sour flavor it balances nicely. The taste is great, it has the right amount of sour from the brett, and the sour cherries that is made palatable through the barrel aging process. I enjoyed this beer, however for a 375ml bottle, $18 seemed a bit much.

2005 Vintage -- black label. This particular vintage was brewed not at Lost Abbey but at Russian River. Interesting trivia. This beer was at a recent tasting.

Beer is brown and hazy. Forms a thin off white head thats broken and diffuse. Carbonation is low but lacing is high.

Aroma is a surprising mix of alcohol and funk. There are some serious sour notes in this beer but the primary aroma is boozy. This is shocking for a 5 year old beer, although it is 11% alcohol.

Taste is complex, its strong and sweet, the sweetness of the beer is almost immediately cut by the sour. There is a hint of cherry flavor in here and then at the end some oak. Drinkability is good and mouthfeel is really good. Its a good beer, I wish I could try a more recent vintage to compare.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle at the RBWG 2011 Grand Tasting. Im pretty excited to finally try this! Pours clear brown, thin tan head, soft lacing. Nose is rich fruit, barrel, caramel, toffee, powerful booze notes, which are a bit off-putting,as are the green apple notes. Some vanilla here too... Flavours of booze, granny smith apples, vanilla oak. Bleugh. Not for me...

The beer pours a dark brown mohagoney with a light tan head. The head only rises about a finger is gone quickly leaving only some bubbles on the rim of the glass. The lacing is light and watery. 

The aroma is strong and complex with lots of flavors. You can tell right away there were wild yeasts as you get lots of funk and vinegar to start. As you peel back the layers you are rewarded further with oak and cherries and vanilla alcohol at the end.

Sadly, the taste is slight let down from the aroma because I was expecting huge varied flavors. Mostly, I just get a sour bitterness that is constant throughout your whole sip. There is not a lof complexity as I was hoping from sweetness from the cherries mixed with some great funk

375ml courtesy of hamilton23.  Pours a murky brown with red highlights.  Damn near no carbonation present right off the bat.  Aside from the large presence of wood and cherries, there is a large amount dark fruit flavors going on in the aroma.  Something else that I just cant describe too.  Lactose maybe? Flavors of caramelized sugar, sweet cherries, wet wood, apple skin and carmalized dark fruits, with super soft carbonation. Just the right amount to complement the dry, rather tannic, finish.  An interesting malt forward sour.  Im happy I got the beer, just think I had higher expectations for it.

I think this is the first beer I added to my wantlist, so I must thank mtjoseph for sharing this.  Bottle opens with only a slight pop.  Pour is murphy brown with pretty much no head.  Aroma is filled with dark fruits, oak, and a very subtle funk.  Im a little nervous about the first sip due to what seems like a very light carbonation.  Taste has cherries, slight sourness towards the mid palate, and an astringent finish.  While I dont think the lack of carbonation hurts this beer too much, I do believe that a bit more would help.  Overall this is an interesting, and good,  beer but maybe it just cant live up to the ideal that I had it at.
Fresh green apple tart aroma.  Murky brown in color.  Cider-like apple sour edge.

750 ml courtesy of Eric, thank you Eric. Poured brown with ruby highlights and an off-white head. Nose had stone fruit, cherry, malts, strong wine like characteristics...tasted tart with a touch of chocolate and cherry. It was acidic with sweet bourbon, and a touch of vanilla.
