It finished dry and very similar in character to an excellent  red wine. Theres a lot happening here. This beer is pretty much the opposite of bad.

2009 bottle, shared with LeopoldStoch. Pours a deep mahogany color with next to no head. The aroma is cherries and other dark fruits followed up by sweet malts, oak, and sourness. The complexity of this beer is insane. With every sip I would get different nuances of dark fruits like dark cherries, grapes, raisins, raspberries as well as notes of oak, vanilla, chocolate and caramel. The finish is dry and This beers fantastic tartness paired with the fact that it is absolutely mouth watering good just has me craving more. Permanently ISO.

An amazing beer.  Similar to Red Poppy but not as good.  A pronounced maple oak-y goodness and sweetness.  A bit sweeter than expected.  A lot more malt (than Red Poppy) but amazing malt.  A bit thicker with more residual sugars.  Amazing, but not quite as good as Red Poppy.  Tasty maple mixed with the maple bark with sweetness.

Lost Abbey Bottle : The downside there is that it isnt a big one like the stock art. Thats a downside because I could have used a lot more of this amazing beer. The aroma of this brew is honestly the highlight of the experience. Pour is dark brown with ruby highlights into this Lost Abbey glass. Head is practically nonexistant; perhaps a light haze. So - really though.. the aroma out of the bottle is amazing stuff in and of itself. In fact, the empty bottle still has an amazing aroma. Toasted Oak, Bourbon, Cherry Pits, but more importantly, an amazing vanilla note as well. The vanilla note is actually what seems to hit the tongue first, with the woody oak character, bourbon, and cherry skins, in that order. If anything the expected tart/bret character is subdued, at least for what you might expect for the style. Anyway - Amazing brew. It was a shocker to see the ABV where it is, honestly.

Bottle. 2007 vintage. Poured into a Duvel tulip glass a slightly murky reddish mahagony color with a slight tan colored head that collars around the glass. Swirling does does some minimal head. Sour cherries right off the bat in the nose along with acetone sourness. Oaky as well. Wow, that has a lot going in the flavor. Sourness right off the bat with a malty belgian backbone. Some red wine type flavors as well in the end along with a dry finish. Light/medium mouthfeel. The 11.5% is in there but not really all that noticeable. Very easy drinking and smooth. Overall, I am very pleased with this in so many ways, the flavors are really nice, the sour/tart is there but not too much, and its carbonated nicely.

Bottle Lost Abbey. Poured a hazy reddish brown color with minimal fizzy off-white head with virtulally no lacing. Moderate to heavy sour cherry, yeast and brown sugar aroma. Medium to full body and a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy sour & sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long duration. This is a complex beer.

750ml bottle shared by Eric, thanks man 
Appearance: Dark brown with a small beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sour fruits, vanilla and woody 
Taste: Sour cherries, oak, vanilla and earthy 
This was great, definitely the stand out beer of the night of many good beers.

Bottle pours deep mohogany with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of sour cherry, caramel, and vanilla. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of brandy soaked prune/plum, sour raisin, oak, and the brett coming through. Overall body is moderate and the acidity is amazing.  This thing is extremely interesting.

29-01-11 Bouteille 2009 du Armsby Abbey (Worcester) et dégustée avec Simon et Gravel: Couleur rouge foncé avec une légère mousse rosée et une toute légère effervescence. Aromes de cerises et de pommes avec des notes vinaigrées.  Moyennement sucrée, avec de fortes notes surettes. Saveurs de pamplemousse rose, de pommes verte, de cerises, de bois, de bourbon et jen passe. Tout ça bien entremêlé. Corps moyen, avec une texture asser volatile qui, par contre, fini par tomber légèrement sur le coeur vue le haut niveau dacidité. Bière très spéciale à essayer au moins une fois, peu importe le prix. (58$)

Bottle.  This is a delicious sour.  Its got tons of sour cherry flavor, but it doesnt quite overwhelm the palate.  Lots of acidity.  Great pucker.  Good funk in the aroma.  Finishes dry and sour.  Its fairly complex, but the barrel notes kinda get lost.  Its a dark brownish red beer with no head, really. Very wine-ish.  Its one of the best from TLA and a wonderfully dry, fruity beer.

2009 bottle shared by madtowndmb1...thanks Kyle! - Pours cola-colored with a very small tan head. Aroma is overripe cherries and malt, decent tartness, and a decent amount of sharp alcohol. Still pretty hot. Tastes caramelly, malty, red wine, and oak. Tastes smooth and bubbly, velvety and with some decent heft.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2013 Bottle 2003 with Simon .Pours black hole deep opaque with absolutely no head and a dead flat appearance. Aroma is outrageous: vanilla, brandy, scotch, oak, chocolate, espresso beans, toasted malts, barley, caramel, toffee, fudge, crème brulée, and maple syrup. Body is full, but not overpowering. Palate is silky velvet smooth with a gentle spice on the front of the tongue. Finish is amazingly calm, mellow, and complex. This 2003 version was the best american sour I have ever had. It became so rich and full flavored from the age and the fact its a different batch from current releases was a nice change of pace. Unreal.
375ml bottle.Pours a burgundy/plum with a tiny white head.Very little carbonation.Nose is bourbon,brett and fruit.Taste is very layered with brett,port,oak,cherry and bourbon.Very stellar beer.

12.7 oz bottle, corked & caged (Lost Abbey 2008 version, sampled 1/12/2011): reassuring pop as the cork is pulledpours a clear, dark mahogany with scarlet highlights.  A pour straight into the glass produces an off-gray, thin head that persists around the edge of the glassPalpable sour cherry aroma with a strong oakiness alongside sweet red grapes and subtle tannins.  Palate is fantastic!  Tiny bubbles and tingly carbonationclose to perfect the years in the cellar have treated this well.  Amazingly tart, lip puckering flavorin some ways shocking and in more ways fabulous!  This proves againdont underestimate Tomme, especially when you give his beers a couple of good years to work! 
750 mL capped bottle (2003, Red Foil #41, sampled 4/25/2005): the deepest garnet; close to black, wow.  Taupe coloured ring of bubbles that is small, but persistent.  The tart aroma assaults the nose instantly as the cap is released.  Soft black cherry notes soothe the senses while bret, sour-aged oaken barrels, strawberry-caramel ice cream and fruity cabernet tingle the nose hairs.  Hints of charred cherry wood and campfire embers add a wonderful depth.  Irony, bretty depth of flavours with sharp oak, vinous cherries and a tang unlike anything I have ever experienced.  Addicting taste  sweet, rich iron and tangy, fruity esters combine with a dry subtle alcohol.  Palate is silky smooth and so full, packed with amazing complexity moist, sour & bitter honey, pineapple rinds & piney yeast.  Thank you Tomme & Jeff, you have put together a simple yet elegant, rare treat.

750 ml brown bottle. 2009 Vintage. Consumed 12/23/10. A murky brown beer with a small head. medium carbonation. The aroma is lactic, tart cherry, vanilla, vinegar, bourbon barrel character. The taste starts off with a tart cherry then with a drying acetic taste that is quickly followed with vanilla that I guess comes from the barrels. Intensely sour. What makes this an interesting sour is the mix of vanilla bourbon barrel character with the extreme sourness. That combo really cuts through your tastes buds to create a very intense experience. So much that finishing just half the bottle was not easy.

Got the chance to try this great beer thanks to a trade!

A- Body is a translucent mildly foggy mahogany hue. Pours with a thin off white collar that fades quickly.

S-Dark fruit, anise, licorice, oak, a touch of alcohol, a slightly sour/acidic presence, and a hint of chocolate malt. Decent overall but more ripe and dark than wild.

T- Large dose of sour cherry upfront-which is quite acidic and slightly lip-puckering. Chocolate malt is very faint in the background. The sourness fades for the finish as smooth vanilla and soaked oak flavors emerge-but then becomes bone dry-and resembles a dark fruity wine.

M- Smooth, full bodied. Slightly dry slightly juicy characteristics. Soft carbonation.

D- This is a VERY good wild ale. Its a nice dark wild ale that is quite complex and quite sour-but not over the top.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-06-2010 01:00:35

Bottle thanks to ygtbsm94: Poured a brown with light bubbles. Aroma is sour with wood and fruit. Taste is similar with sour wood and very dead finish. Not very carbonated and once again I missed the boat on what I should enjoy from this.
Pours dark brown with little head. Aroma is raisins with sour black cherries and alcohol. Oh, wonderfully sour with cherries. Very acidic, but in an awesome way. This is delicious.

2009. Shared with a local BA on 09.23.2010.

Pop. My notes play the association game more than anything with this one, so Ill stay true to myself, and this review will be some of my stream of consciousness - after all, a large part of enjoying a beer is with how it makes one feel and what it makes one think of - and the rest will be description.

Pours a murky, dark redwood with a finger-nail of head ringing the edge of the glass. 

The nose reminds me of playing hide and seek, hiding in a pull-off air conditioning grate with a claustrophobic companion. Theres an almost vomit-like attribute: solventy, with a deep cherry sourness, along with figs and strong vinegar. 

Very tart and vinegary; think of sour cherry/cranberry juice. Small hints of bourbon and brown sugar from the quadruple base, along with cherry pits, and a good bit of earthy funkiness on the finish. Quite abrasive in most respects. Creamy in the mouth. 

Im sitting in the grass, as it rains. It is quiet, and Im alone -

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 271210.
Brown with small head. Aroma of sourness and wood. Flavor with notes of fruit but the sourness is too unbalanced

Huge thanks to barleypops for brining this to the QC tasting, 2005 bottle 750 bottle, poured a clear brown with little head, aroma was full of funk, sour fruit and a hint of whiskey, overall the flavor was sweet in the front end with a sour ending thta has great notes of fruit, truly a delicious brew.

12/23/10.  2005 bottle courtesy barleypops at the QC Christmas tasting!  Whoa, this is crazy...  Huge whiskey BA aroma with a dash of sour cherries, chocolate, and coconut.  A hint of sour at first followed by cherry, chocolate, mint, a tad of veggies, bitter wood tannis, and more.  This is a bit odd, interesting, and... good!

Lost Abbey
Cuvee De Tomme 2009
Thank you to Ryan and Brenna. Merry Christmas. Let me start this by saying that I am not a fan of sours, but I am trying and this shit is not the easiest in the world to get. Pours dark brown with a reddish tinge to the edges. Very little head, probably due to the age. Aroma is red wine all the way, with notes of alcohol, grapefruit peels and sour cherries. Flavor is grapefruit, red wine, sour cherries, bourbon oak and alcohol. Sour, but not for the sake of being sour. Actually very drinkable in limited quantities. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this, but I was a few beers deep, so that may have helped. I could see the quality, even though it was not my type.

2008 bottle.  Aroma has notes of sour cherries, brett funk, wood, red wine, toasty malts.  Murky dark reddish brown with a small tan bubbly head that fully diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is heavy sweet and sour.  Palate is full bodied and average carbonation.  Finish is a little cloying and the alcohol is slightly noticeable.  Overall a very lovely brew that looks like shit.  Great nose, great flavor and good palate.  2+ years have been very kind.  Enjoyed it immensely.

37.5cl cork/cage 2008 traded bottle. Pours a darker than expected brown with only a hint of a head that settles into a bubbly, tan ring. Sharp aroma of sour cherries and brett that makes your mouth water. Nice sour flavor that does not completely obscure the quality base beer. Well done.

375mL bottle purchased at the Pizza Port Carlsbad bottle shop in August 2009.

A: Pours a nice dark brown with a clingy white head and plenty of lacing.

S: Sweet tartness from the cherries, with the quadrupel aspect of the brew coming through underneath with a bit of a nose from the barrel.

T: Tart cherries, a bit sour, but not too puckering. Not as complex as the nose led on, but a very tasty beer. The balance between the tartness and sourness of the cherries compared with the quadrupel base could be a bit better, but no major complaints.

M: A tad bit puckering for some dryness. Medium-bodied.

D: Very tasty all around and one that sat well for quite some time. Glad I picked this one up.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-10-2010

Small beige head. Opaque dark brown body. Earthy roasty chocolatey aroma with vinegary wax and oil notes. Dry-sour vinegar cherry and wax taste with chocolatey notes. Mid-bodied. Sharpish mouthfeel. Dry vinegary cherry and roasty soy sauce aftertaste with wooden metallic notes. Quite nice, and somewhat unusual. (0.375l bottle shared by gr0ve.)
Balsamico aroma, soy sauce, very salt, dry. More like a sauce than a beer? Fresh sourness as the salt fades away. Weird.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2013 Tomme might be the biggest bitch in the brewing universe, but the man sure can make a good sour, if its carbonated that is .. . Pours a light red tan .. . flavours of assorted berries, wood, cherry, jolly ranchers, funk, and titty residue .. . just an awesome libation, just a pity its made by such a twat .. . You hold it or else Ill break it off and kick it around on the ground!

2009 - This is the second one Ive had - this one is a little more sour and less fruity.  Smells like soured fruit, cherries, vinegar. Tastes delicious.  Makes your cheeks pucker.  Vinegar, sugar, sour cherries, hibiscus. Thin mouthfeel.  Pair with a lobster roll from Boston.

Sampled at a Freetail release, bottle share. Courtesy of me.  375ml, 09.  Pours a dark brown body with red highlights.  Aromas are sour berries, sour apples, funk, tart and some woody notes.  Immediately acetic on the tongue.  Makes my saliva glands explode.  Flavors, after the saliva flood, are sweet/sour, berry tartness, fermented stone fruits and an acidic lingering quality.  Very complex and not a hint of alcohol in the nose or palate. A taste Im acquiring.

Brown red pour, 
Aroma is Funk, Earth, Black Cherry, Red cherry, light acetic acid, lacto funk.  
Mouthfeel is creamy, Flavors are bold and lovely.  Earthy, funky sour brown ale style, very complex and robust.  A real pleasure to drink

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2012 I had this on tap at the beer for brains event in Phoenix, AZ. Aromas are wonderful, lime, cherries, and oak. The taste is hugely sour. Sour cherries, barnyard flavors, lemons, dark sour blackberries dominate. So sour and so good if you like the crazy sour beers.
2005 bottle courtesy of ygtbsm94 - how DOES he come up with these?  Chestnut color, no head.  Aroma of prunes and raisins, taste of port wine.  Tasty.
Deep caramel/red copper color with nice, light lacing. Aroma is of sour caramel. Its a little too sour for my taste. Reminds me of a fine flavored vinegar.

09 bottle at brewery.  Aroma is sweet cherry, oak (bourbon?), and maybe some chocolate.  Cherry dominates in the taste with a wonderful dryness.  Tart, sweet cherry - dry and funky on the finish.  Excellent.
Had at lost abbey. Pour is a deep red or Burgundy. Aroma is phenomenon of funk, sour and malts. Flavor is a great balance of funky spurs and vanilla malts. Really enjoyable.

(375ml bottle at Lost Abbey-2009 edition).  Pours red-brown with no head.  Aroma is a nice mix of raisin, Cherry and Bourbon (yeah, I read the label but those ingredients are noticeable.  Sweet followed by sour.  Chery followed by raisin by bourbon.  Medium bodied with oily texture.  Smooth finish with bourbon and sourness.  Unique sour that is very well made.

2009 bottle. Reddish orange body, clear. Off-white head, rapidly diminishing. Funky aroma of barnyard, cherry, wood, vanilla and alcohol. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter and moderately acidic. It finishes moderately sweet, moderately acidic and lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, moderate carbonation. Lots of barnyard from the brett and tart cherries in the taste. Subtle complexity. Leather, plum, vanilla. Nice  mouth-puckering, acidic finish.

Sample at SBWF 2010. Dark red-brown without head. Wonderful aroma, complex, sour, fruity, funky... My words arent enough to describe its flavours, but its so good. The sourness is perfect! The alcohol just adds to the complexity, but theres not a trace of it in the taste, barely even a warming sensation. I would love to have a bottle of this in my cellar.

Sample at SBWF, sold as Lost Abbey Cuvee de Tomme. 

A fantastic beer. Complex and full of different flavors. A lot of berries, oak, vinegar, citrus. Very nice sourness, almost perfect mouth feel. I think that I am in love, can you love a beer? Of course you can!

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2013 Wow!  2010 off centered exp. Still feel new to the sour / wild beer experince.  This makes a believer of me.  From the bottle,  a background of cherries with woodyness.  Well blended, smooth.  Alcohol not noticeable.  Vinegary, complex.  Need more!   First rate was 2010 Oct.  Got another bottle.  Aromas of wood, cherries, and brett.  Very tart, mix with cherries with a dry finish.  Like it even better.

2009 bottle. 900 th rating for my birthday. Well - its good. No arguments there. It was also flat. The real problem was the brett. I like how orval has a touch of brett to compliment and improve an already great brew. Here the brett dances all over this beer so the base beer really struggles to show its true value. Slight vanilla, a bit of cherry and heaps of funk.  I like funky beers, but a beer that starts as a quad with rasins and is aged in different barrels should really not be overshadowed by horse blanket. Its still a good beer, but was definitely a bit of a let down. Maybe with some carbonation it may have made all the difference. If this was the same price as consecration it may have scored more highly too. $33 plus postage to Australia  and was overshadowed by a 5% lindemans cuvee kriek. Still glad to try this and look forward to visting lost abbey on my san diego trip in december!

Hazy, ruddy brown pour with no head.  Tons of oak and berries, with notes of molasses, dark fruit, deep cherry, vanilla, bourbon, black pepper, toasted oak, and bourbon.  Amazing depth and complexity!  Every sip is a different component of the beer.  Dry, creamy, medium body with lots of carbonation.

12.7 oz bottle of the 2009 vintage from AmEricanbrew. Pours clear ruby and brown with a tiny head from a hard pour that fizzes out to nothing, also has big wine like legs. Big aroma of cherries, vinegar, oak, boozy bourbon and some light musty, earthy scents. The flavor is extremely sour, some lactic, vinegar and barnyard sourness. There is also a lot of barrel and alcohol flavors, the fruit is more subdued than the aroma would suggest. Medium body with a mild carbonation and a dry mouth feel. Dont think Ive ever had such a big, sour, dry beer. Thanks for this one Eric, truly a unique beer.

from Erzbierschof.ch; 2009 vintage - hazy bordeaux-brown colour with no head retention; very complex aroma of wood, burnt almonds, cocoa and vinegar; full-bodied and very sour; a moderate and subtle carbonation, quite dry and very sour finish with long notes of vinegar, wood, nut and apples - a wonderful beer

Bottle, courtesy of Phredrik. Dark brown colour with a small, off-white head. Nice aroma with candy, burnt sugar, apple tart, vinegary sweet-and-sour-ish characteristics, oak, brett and vanilla. Awesome and enticing! Taste is massively sour with tons of oak and port-wine, while also retaining the vinegary sourness. Also some fruit-tarts. Very fresh! Medium carbonation, big body, long duration. Epic!

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 Small bottle shared by MartinT.
Appearance : Very small head. Short retention.

Aroma : Very complex nose. Notes of sour cherries. Red fruits and light hops. Light raisins and brett. Very fresh !

Taste : Nice sour cherries, red fruits and some brett. Finish quite woody.

Overall : Very nice brew. Nice fruits on nose and taste. Nice sourness, not overwhelming. Not very lactic. Little something that bugs me on the finish. Maybe its the astringency. Still a very nice beer that Im very happy to have finally tried. Thanks Martin ! 
Re-rate 100917 : Fixed typos.

Bottle at Monks to celebrate Dallas engagement.  Few beers can live up to the quality of this brew.   A masterful blend of raisens, cherries, bourbon, vanilla, and wild yeast.   One of the few, if not the only beers that simaltaniously attacks the palate with a near overwhelming tart characteristics while also delivering smooth melt-in-your-mouth bourbon vanilla mellowness.  A real treat.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2010 Nice dark red/brown pour with minimal head. Aroma is a symphony of vanilla, oak, cherries, brett, candy sugar, winegums, very vineous and rum like, earthy, basement aromas. The taste is fucking otherworldly with a cherry explosion, brett balance, lovely tartness, lovely oak and vanilla, just bloody amazing. Every once in a while you drink a beer that makes you forget all worries and simply makes you happy. This is one of the beers that just makes everything all right.

Bottled 375ml. Murky reddish brown with a small bubbly head. Christmas pudding, cherries, raisin, vinegar, port, wood and walnuts in the nose. Very complex, astringent with practically no carbonation. Quite a lot of cherries showing up again in the taste. Full bodied with alcohol only bringing a slight warming sensation on the swallow- nice. I am not a big fan of the malt profile. I think this is a masterpiece of a beer. Flawless and wonderful in any case- but I doesnt entirely work for my tastes. The angels share stays the epitome beer from port brewing/ lost abbey for me.

Bottled. Deep rubyish amber colour with a small beige head. Aroma is sour cherries, cherry pips, some mildvanilla, alcohol as well as dark dry fruits. Also some mild plum and sour wooden notes. Flavour is sour wood, sour cherries, some mild vanilla, mild wood as well as some slight spices and alcohol. Actually quite beautifully balanced.

Bottled from de Molen, 2009. Hazy redbrown color, short head, some lacing. Aroma of marzipan cherry, bit cookie, raisin, red wine. Very complex, each sniff brings up new aromas. Quite tart, fruity, bit sweet, slight sparkling. Soft alcohol burn. Lovely stuff.

Bottled, Lost Abbey Cuvee de Tomme, thanks to caesar for sharing. Opaque, small head. Very fruity nose, alcoholic, vanilla, marzipan, cookie dough. An explosion of flavor, very sour, lambic like, tart, vanilla, very long lasting, alcohol doesnt dominate. Dry finish which doesnt really match with the flavor. Although not all flavors are in absolute harmony, this is still a very nice experiment.

Bottle (2009). Clear redbrown color, no head. Sour aroma with old apples, aged wine and milk chocolate. Bitter-sour taste of wet wool blanket, fruits and cherries. Full body. The most complex drink I´ve had, can´t wait to try it again!

Labeled as Lost Abbey Cuvee de Tomme 2009. Pours out in a cloudy reddish brown colour with a small bubbly off-white head. Rich deep and really fruity and woody aroma of black cherries, blackberries, honey, mild brett and lactic acid. Full-bodied with rich notes of of black cherries, brett, wood, lemon-zest and tart cherry-skins. Long fruity dryish aftertaste of black cherries, brett and wood. Beautiful stuff.

2008 375ml bottle into DFH snifter.
A nice pop, which is a good start.

A - Pours brown with a reddish hue. More brown toward the bottom of the glass but more red towards the top. A good amount of cream colored head and lots of fizzy bubbles, almost champagne-like. A very small amount of lacing, just a very thin ring around the glass that leaves a hint.

S - A huge nose on this one. You can smell the tart/sour of this beer across the room. Lots of oak, tart fruitiness such as sour cherries or sour grapes. Not a huge amount of complexity going on here, but its amped up so much it makes for a great experience.

T - Sour cherries right off the bat mixed with a nice mellow oaky flavor that has a kick of alcohol (but nothing that would lead me to believe its 11%). Drinks very similar to a wine...lots of flavors up front with a smooth oak & alcohol finish.

M - Light to medium bodied with good carbonation. No problems at all from my bottle, just right. I think some people expect so much carbonation, it just pours over, but with this style, its just not the case. Very smooth, refreshing, and clean.

D - So easy to drink for 11%, its just dangerous. If I wanted a nice Pinot Noir or Cab and had a bottle of this laying around, Id have to do a coin toss to pick what Id like to drink. CdT or a Napa Cab/Russian River Pinot...its that good.
Shared this with my daughter in Oakland. Fantastic, perfect sour aroma and flavor. Period.

(Bottled, rated 2010-03-02) Quite clear, dark ruby color with a small and bubbly, beige head. Lots of tart cherries in the nose with dark fruitiness and some alcohol warmth. Flavor is pretty sour, cherryish, slightly raisiny, and even sugary. Quite full body with slightly fizzy and high CO2. A very tart and intense sour ale, that reminds me of Panil Barriquée Sour - yet is not as drinkable.
Pours stagnant dark brown With no head. Extremely tart palate with a heavy oak flavor accompanied by sour cherries. A solid brew

09 bottle. Pours a really dark red color. Has a sour cherry smell to it. At first you get sour cherries then it you can pick up some wood, brett, and candied sugar. I must say after having on 05 bottle I think this best drank fresh.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 2008 bottle consumed at the Toronado.

A: Dark reddish-brown body. Moderate off-white cap. Moderate retention with just a hint of lacing left behind.

S: Candi sugar, cherries, raisins, slightly sour. Good oaky and bourbon hints. 

T: Good sour cherry flavor takes center stage. Again the oak and bourbon is present throughout. I like the elements from the base of the beer, figs and raisins. Good caramel and roasted malts underneath. 

M: Slightly chewy, with good carbonation levels. Slightly oily finish.

O: I polished this bottle of fairly quickly. Certainty an enjoyable brew.

370ml Lost abbey bottle.

Pours brown redish.

Fruity, sweet, plums and red berries. Not very sour...

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were quickly diminishing and left behind a no visible carbonation ruby red brown colored body and a poor lacing. The mild aroma was licorice. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of tart sour lambic like and funk. An OK brew just nothing special.

750ml bottle.  2009.  Pours a cloudy brown, ruby color with a slight fizzy white head.  Aroma is cherry tartness and funk.  Nice sour aroma as well.  Taste is sour and funky with a good amount of tart cherry.  Medium body with a little bit of stickiness.  There is some heat once it hits the stomach.  This is very good.
Shared with james and pat at monks. Dark brown color with a funky nose. Syrupy look with little head. Very sour taste with an amazing mouthfeel. Not very puckery to the mouth and perfect carbonation

Bottle. Pours red-brown. No head. Cherries (and some strawberries), small earthiness, vinousity and some caramel/butter notes in the aroma. The sourness is moderate. This is a rather fruity and sweet brew. Small bitterness. Wood in the aftertaste. A quite smooth brew with some dryness in the finish.

Bottle. Pours a clear, dark copper beer with a weak offwhite head. The aroma is complex with tart, fruit and sourness. The flavor is tart, sour, wood, bourbon, cherries and redwine. The palate is acidity. Overall a good beer, but not one of my personal favorite styles.

375 ml bottle of 2009 vintage purchased at the brewery on release day around a year ago ($15).  Pours a muddy brown with noticeable hints of red around the edges.  Only a thin whisper of tan head quickly disappears into nothingness.  Aroma is rich with sour cherries, vinegar, wood, and light funk.  Though the aroma is tart at first, there are other sweeter notes of port wine and vanilla.  As with the aroma, the very sour cherries stand out first in the taste.  Dry oak, acidic vinegar, and some mellow funk also reside in the taste.  The finish is dry with lingering tart fruitiness.  The very high ABV is dominated by the tartness and basically imperceptible.  Im still getting into sours, and this one is great for my learning curve.  (616, 325)

Big thanks to Sarah for sharing this one!

A-pours a cloudy mahogony colored liquid.  the vigourous pour produces a thin small amount of khaki colored head.

S-the nose is nice, notes of earthy musk, oak, cherries, vinegar, and some tartness.

T-the taste is quite nice, a touch of earthiness to it up front, notes of vinegar, the oak lies right behind with a good bit of cherries and cranberries behind.  the back has a good bit of tartness to it in a nice way.

M-smooth with a good medium body, prickly on the back of the throat and actually more carbonation than I thought after the poor.

D-quite tasty, great balance.  i really enjoyed the the hint of earth to up the complexity with the sour tart cherries.  the oak is played in pretty well also.

375ml bottle, 2009 edition, courtesy of sparky27. thanks, eric! pours a deep, dark, ruby red with no head but a light effervescence that leaves a razor thing ring of light khaki lace. aroma is beautiful and fantastically complex with big, tart, red cherries, pie filling, grapes, and light vinegar up font with delicately sweet notes of caramel, oak, vanilla, and angels food cake spiked with a hint of funk and wet leather. flavor is wonderful as well with massively sour fruit notes of cherry, un-ripe purple grapes, and lemon zest backed by musty funk and subtly, dry, and slightly sweet oak and caramel malts. palate is full bodied with light but very appropriate carbonation and a lingery, dry, tart finish. overall, a wonderful, unique sour.

2009 375ml bottle. Pours a bright ruby red color that is topped by a small, bubbly tan colored head of foam that settles quickly to a thin film. Some sudsy lace drips slowly down the glass. The aroma is really nice and complex showing a lot of fruity character with soured cherries, cherry pits, grapes, and raisins. The brown ale base consists of caramel malts and oaky vanilla. The brett adds a touch of dryness and a little wild character. The flavor follows and shows a good amount of tartness with the sour cherries, raisins, and other tart berries pushing their way to the front. The oak adds a nice woody character along with the brett lending its signature tartness to the flavor profile. The oaky vanilla seems to smooths things out from being overly sour. The mouthfeel is medium bodied, slightly dry on the palate and finely carbonated, which leads to a sour cherry finish. The alcohol is noticeable on the finish, but not overly so. This is a complex sour ale with lots of components, and a great beer all around.

Shared with svoger and beerbiker at my bicycle weekend debut. Dark brown hazy look with a small brown head. Nice aroma of overripe cherries with lots of eartheren and woody notes. Has the belgian sour ale aroma aswell. Flavor is medium acidic balanced by a light sweetness. Great balance actually, and great beer

375ml bottle, 2009 vintage.  Pours a nearly opaque, purple amber with zero head.  Fruity aroma, light funk, light cheese, light feet, vinegar.  Flavor is sweet, malts, caramel, cherries, bourbon, wood, tart with that pedio character, vinegar.  Finish is full bodied and acidic with very light carbonation.  Lots of oak in the flavor and also in the mouthfeel.

Bottle at PilsnerPeters RBSG 2010.  The aroma is sour cherries, other fruits, very inviting.  The appearance is a hazy brown, almost no head.  The flavor is sour cherries, vinegar.  The finish is pure sourness, again like vinegar.  Medium in body.  Very nice, enjoyable sour.

11-UN-2010, bottle @home, from "Fish & Beer", 2009 vintage.
World Cup soccer on TV. Second half and by now it is the right temperature, and a perfect drink.
I am not a huge sour fan, but maybe I am starting to appreciate it?
Is this like wine drinkers ending up in Bourgogne? Beer geeks go from hops to sour?
Anyway, this is a nice brownish, perhaps slightly red color, with little head. Nose is fantastic. Vanilla, cherries, tartness, brown sugar.
Taste is refreshingly sour and slightly sweet at the same time .
No doubt that this has seen barrels. No clue where the alcohol is at?
Soccer? - France - Uruguay, still 0-0, but who cares. This bottle has lasted the whole match, and goes on improving, showing new sides.
Never had a Lost Abbey that was less than exeptional;)
Bottle at Peters 2nd annual spring gathering.   Reddish with ring.  Funky woody cherry aroma.  Woody funky cherry wine with woody earthy bitter finish.  Soft palate.  Complex and freaking excellent.

2009 version 375ml bottle.

Appearance: dark brown with ruby corners and little to no head.

Smell: Nice raisin, cherry, dark malt, sour goodness combo going on!

Taste: Loads of sour cherries dominate the flavor profile. Up my alley but probably not up everybodys.

Mouthfeel: Way undercarbonated.

Drinkability: Good despite the high abv and fair amount of sourness.

Rushed review....my apologies.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-03-2009

This poured a dark red to brown color with a very small head. Aroma was sour cherries, alcohol, brett, yeast and some funk. Flavor was just incredible tartness upfront, both from the cherries and the wild yeast, then some alcohol warmth, then a nice funky oaky bourbon finish. A world class beer indeed.

Bottle from Peters RBSG. Dark prune pour, headless. I was scared of the aroma: bad whiskey, brown sugar, and cherry. Thick, obnoxious aroma that was a bit off putting. Not at all what Id want in a sour. The flavor is sour and bitter: lemon, raspberry, nail polish, and whiskey. Tart finish of lemon and some sort of sweet fruit, maybe papaya. This got better with time and once I knew what to expect, but damn is it obnoxious. The tart qualities are really nice; Id just like less of everything else.
Bottle at PilsnerPeters RBSG 2010 courtesy of Brian. Pours a dark muddy reddish brown. Nose is sweet cherry and cherry skin. Taste is very cherry tart.

Bottle @ UDRM, as Lost Abbey Cuvee de Tomme. The aroma has cherries, caramel malts, barnyard. Bit hazy, brown coloured beer with a small head. The taste is sour, little sweet, tart and has cherries, some citrus, caramel malts. Quite tart and dry.

Lost Abbey label, 2009 vintage.  Pours a muddy, reddish brown, almost no head.  First sip, well, Ive never puckered quite like I did with this brew.  Strong presence of cherries (almost like cherry fruit leather), but nicely balanced with malts, wild yeast with some cheese overtones,  Ive been a bit disappointed with Lost Abbey in the past, but this is an excellent beer.

0.375 l bottle (vintage 2009) at Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Dark reddish brown color, head vanishes quickly. Very acidic and perfumed aroma with cherry, leather, grapefruit and gentle oak. Sharp acidic flavor with cherry, chocolate, soya sauce, oak and black currants. Medium to full body. Warming palate. Very complex.
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Red, brown colored brew. Aroma is raisins. Flavor is sour, raisons.
color of deep prune juice, aroma of sour raisins and deep malt. Flavor is a dry pruney cherry maltiness. Bottle from the brewery, San Diego.

Bottle at Göteborg beer festival, 2010-04-23 Göteborg
grapfruit, pomegranate, oaked flavor, sourness, tarts, nuts/rasin, figs - super!

2009 750ml. pours a thick burgundy, slightly hazy and opaque, little head, some spotting. aroma is surprisingly malty underneath the initial sour note. some notes of faint oak, subtle fruit. the taste is very tart, dry and sour. very intense in the front to mid palate. good, but i cant drink this whole thing, just too tart. there is more fruiot in the aftertaste, and the finish is nice. it leaves me wanting more, but when i actually drink it the sourness is a bit much.

2009 375mL bottle. Sharp acidity with light cherry notes. Pours brown with no head but nice lacing from the initial pours foam. Big sourness and very dry. Fruity without much sweetness, just enough to balance the sourness. Lingering sourness. Palate is dry dry dry but silky.

Bottle @ RB meeting by Joes. A clear dark amber/brown colored beer, with no head. The aroma of dark fruits with alcohol. The taste of dark fruits with sourness. Notes of wood with some alcohol. The aftertaste is dry bitter with wood.

375 ml bottle; 2009 vintage via Sinners Club; healthy popping of the cork and pours light brown with thin, off-white head; slight sour overtones with chocolate, cherries and figs; rich and intoxicating nose; creamy texture with an obvious fizzy sourness; dry, tart with citrus and nuts; thickens up and complexity grows as it warms; brett is very nice as it is bone dry, but never too sour or astringent from the cherries; mild vinegary texture and flavor; oak, cherries, grape skins; musky, oaky and slight sticky finish; killer nose and just a great beer all around; still one of my fav from Lost Abbey

Original Rating 8/27/08 (4.1)  375 ml bottle via Sinners; 2008 vintage; my first taste at the Brouwers Sour Fest a few months back was very underwhelming, so Im glad I have a few bottles to revisit; pours dark brown with almost no head; aromas are earthy, tart, slightly funky, cherries and very red wine-ish; slight cream and warm texture to the body; also a little fizzy, which I guess is more from the yeast and cherry combo; very impressed this time around; complex and delicate with dry, fruity finish; sourness muted and mixed well

Pours deep, dark red, almost brown, haloed off-white spritzy head, from the 750ml bottle into a wine glass: Nose of dark cherries, oak, smoke, damp basement, brett, and vanilla. Complex, vinious flavor notes of oak, bret, figs, grapes, and cherries. Drinkability: Bold and plump. Pairing: Fruit tart. Rebuy: Yeah, although I believe its a tad overrated. #398 on 15042010, DG.
Pours brown with a tan head. Aroma is fruit, sour, cherries, oak, complex and malty notes in the background. Flavour is sour, acidic, cherries, oak and malty background.

Bottle @ Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours unclear dark brown with a small creamy bubbly head. Nose is complex of chocolate, berries, red wine, vinegar and brett. Heavy dry , slick and tart flavor with some fresh cherries and brett. Warmth. The tartness lasts thorughout. Delicious and complex beer!

Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing jbrus! Pours a clear amber to copper color without any head. Aroma of cherries and fruity bretts. Flavor is very sour, fruity, slightly spicy and with some leathery bretts. Quite nice balance, not too sour and with delicious fruits.
Bottle at Dahlberg. Sour cherries and sweet malt in a good balance. Sweet and sour in taste cherries cherryjuice dark malt vanilla fudge and a long sour cherry aftertaste.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Helsinki. Reddish-brown color, slight tan head. Lambic aroma. Sour cherry flavor with notable tannins and a fairly dry finish. Full body, medium carbonation. Its interesting, Ill give you that, but I dont really see what the big deal is, its just "ok". If I want superb sour beers Ill stick to Cantillon.

Got to try a bottle of this in January 2010. Colour... ruby-brown with no head. Nose... sweetly, gleeking-ly acidic and fruity. Palate... nice CO2, tart, balanced, kirschwasser, macerated pie cherries, cherry stems, yeast and a helluva long finish!

GABF 09.Pours a deep, cloudy amber sap with a nose of cedar plank chips soaked in cherry juice.  Flavor is cherry sour, wet cedar, and lemon zest.  Lingers on the tongue.  Delicous.  Cant have enough of this.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours deep red with off white head, aroma cherry, oak, vanilla, and sour notes. Taste up front is sugar with some lemon and citrus but quickly fades into a huge blast of cherry tart and a long sour finish.   Sour red at its best.

From bottle at City Beer. Subtle complex nose - tart, lactic, oaky, chocolate, vanilla, light licorice, winey - just one of the best beer noses Ive experienced in a long time. Murky ruby brown with light tan lacing head. Medium body, voluptuous and silky with medium carbonation. Starts with great sour tang, oaky and lactic, bittersweet chocolate and licorice, apple skin and chardonnay. Just really well balanced and sublime. Great beer.

tap at Toronado in San Diego-man was i glad to have a sample of this-there is NO way i would be able to finish a pint of this monster of a beer.  pours brown with a lite spritzy off-white head.  brett, oak, cherries, sour, vanilla on the nose-i can tell this thing is young, but with some age, this would be a truely complex monster of a beer.  as it was, it was pretty complex-figs, sour grapes, oak, vineous notes-strong and bold.  big alcoholic red grapes dominate though at this young age.  needs some age, but this vintage will age awesome, at least i can sense it will.  a really cool brew that i would like to try again sometime.

Bottled 0,375l vintage 2009 @Pikkulintu
Dark brown color, small beige head. Aroma of sour cherries, cellar and bretta. Medium-bodied. Cherry-fruity, lots of bretta, cellary-mouldy notes. Long sour fruity aftertaste. Very Belgian.

2009 vintage. 750ml. 11%. Pours dark brown, near opaque, fizzy at first, then still, with little apparent carbonation after a minute. Aroma is indeed of sour cherries, brown sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg. Complex aroma that I like a lot. Flavor is a battle between sour brett and heavy sweet malt, and I like witnessing this confrontation. The cherries and other fruits come around later. Lots of wood toward the end, no bourbon showing. Fuller mouthfeel, a little dead on the palate due to the lack of carbonation. Overall, excellent.
Avery Sour Ale Fest.  Definitely one of the highlights of the fest.  Oak, funk, some brown sugar, and some nice fruity sourness.  One hell of a beer.

(Bottle, 0.375 l - 2009 vintage, at Pikkulintu)  Poured very deep red and hazy with small and white head. Aroma contained sourness, malts, dates, berries, fruitiness and sweetness.  Palate was medium bodied, warming and dry with quite high carbonation.  Flavours were extreme sourness, berries, wood, fruitiness and low bitterness. Aftertaste was sour.

Draught at Sour Fest. Murky brown with small white head. Aroma of funkiness, basement mildew, aged goat cheese, sour feet and light caramel/molasses. Taste is big sour caramel funk with nice malt depth. Very acidic and does not feel like 11%. Goof carbonation and medium bodied

Sampled from the bottle at the 2010 February Circle City Tasting. Poured a hazy amber brown with a medium light brown bubbly head. Aroma had a nice combination of oak, tart cherries, other sour fruits and a bit of barnyard funk. Flavor sour throughout with some cherry notes and an undertone of earthy notes.

Pours deep red with off white head, aroma right away is huge cherry, oak, vanilla, and some other fruits with a huge tart nose.  Taste up front is subtle vanilla, sugar, some lemon and citrus but quickly fades into a huge blast of cherry tart and a long sour finish.  Unbelievable brew, wish I could have this all the time.  One of my favorites!

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 smag kirsebær eddike uds.kastanie brun uklar bundfald skum ingen,e.smag lidt sød, tung bitter eddikke  feb 10 @f1 eller døe ho

rerate Aroma:malt alc grape kirsebær  Ud.:kobber Skum:hvidt  E.smag:sur moderat Krop:medium For.:tør Brus:blød  
27/1-12 @f1 
8 3 9 3 19 =4,2

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2010 Bottle at Monks for the Lost Abbey dinner, with Tomme Arthur. Pours a shiny, hazy amber brown with a crazily thin, off-white head. Aroma of brown sugar, malts, vinegar, barley, dry grapes, honey, lemon, and juicy dry hops. Body is medium with to full with a biting, tiart, loose mouthfeel. Finishes strong and bitter. Excellent all around and great finish to a fantastic evening. 

Re-rate: initial rating: 4.5 
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a vinegar amber brown with zero head and a slight trace of lace around the edges. Aroma of tart, bitter dark cherries, fresh merlot grapes, balsamic vinegar, Granny Smith apples, currants, figs, walnut, lemon zest, subtle bitter hops, and sweet malts. Medium, silky body with a chewy, sticky, insanely sour palate. Finishes long, slow, and with an acidic bite. Overall, this is a truely refined, elegant, unique, masterfully crafted brew. Hats off to you, Tomme, for this sublime, wonderful beer. Perfect.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2014 RERATE: Bottle shared with Linh while in Georgia. Pours a deep murky brown body with light lacing. Aroma is a wonderful combination of tart cherry, deep chocolate, oak and bourbon. The wood/oak character comes through again on the palate, along with flavors of tart, chocolate-covered cherries, molasses, brown sugar, dark fruit, bourbon and light warming in the finish. On most occassions, one of the best beers Ive ever had. 

ORIGINAL RATING: Last beer sampled during the night at monks with Tomme Arthur. Pours a dark, dark brownish red body. Aroma is tart, some fruit - maybe cherry.  Flavor is ridiculous, mainly notes of tart cherry,

A: A dark brown with reddish tints. A bit of off-white foam sits on top.

S: Tart cherries, a bit of alcohol, and bit of funk.

T: The predominant flavor is the tart cherry. There is also some sour apple and raisins. The finish is quite earthy, probably from the Brett.

M: Medium bodied, good carbonation, and quite tart.

D: A great all around experience. Great flavor and sourness.

2009 bottle.Pours a deep rouge with a fizzy head. Aroma of sour cherries and alcohol. A lot less brettanomyces flavors than I was expecting. Very drinkable with a great flavor of those sour cherries and sweet belgian candy sugar. The alcohol is hidden well. An amazingly well crafted ale. Tomme Arthur is amazing.

Bottle of the 2009 vintage on 01/29/2010.  A dark brown color with light reddish hints.  A light brown head.  An intense, powerful sour cherry, cinnamon, wood, and apple aroma.  Rich, full bodied, extremely sour but balanced with enough malty punch and spicy finish that settles in eventually.  Long gloriously sour aftertaste.

375 2008 bottle, pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is full of horseblanket and cherries.  Some burnt sugar too.  Flavor is very strong brett with some light vanilla and moldy wood.   Ends with a tart cherry skin and apple skin flavor.  Nice and different.

( 375ml bottle 2009 vintage thanks to mar) Pours opaque garnet with thin oily bubbles on top. Nose of bourbon, brown sugar, tart cherries, wood and olives. Taste of alcohol, tart cherries, mouth puckering sourness, unripened plum and skin, star fruit, bourbon, and extremely complex. Tart finish with tons of complexity. This is a phenomenal beer.

750 mL bottle from South Bay (2009 Vintage).  Muddy brown pour that appears dark brown with ruby highlights in the glass.  Virtually no head.  Very slight Belgian yeast aroma but mostly this is overwhelmed by very tart cherries and an acidic apple cider vinegar.  Holy crap, this is sour!   But on the back end is a wonderfully balanced oak character that lends almost as much to the flavor as the cherries.  The alcohol is not evident in the flavor but does add a touch of warmth.  One of the most complex sour beers I have ever been fortunate enough to taste and one of the best.  I paid $30 for this and it was worth every penny (glad I bought 2 of them).  Absolutely incredible.

Bottle. 2009 vintage.

Murky brown with a small tanned head that leaves some lacings.

The smell is complex and balanced with notes of brett, sour cherries, grass, mud and malts. A hint of vanilla in the nose as well. 

The flavor is tart with pleasant cherry notes, funky brett, grass and some liqueur-like fruity notes. Lightly sweet malts and notes of wood in the foundation. The finish is dry and lightly bitter with notes of wood, cherries and just a hint of alcohol. 

Medium body and well balanced carbonation.

A really good beer. Complex, interesting and tasty - what more can you ask for?

Bottle shared at a Portland BA/RB tasting held at Baileys Taproom...  [Lost Abbey bottle] Poured amber with a thin head.  Tart, sour, yeast funk on the nose.  Dry, stripping the palate greatness to it.  Fermented fruit sugar notes and a nice warming tone as well with sweet malts for balancing the tartness.
Bottle at the Toronado. Aroma of cherry, apple and malt. Flavor is at first very tart, and then the blackberry and oak come out. Glad to have tried it, though perhaps not a beer to drink regularly.

Bottle shared with Goethe. My notes are pretty slim on my blackberry, so Ill have to open the 2nd bottle (or the 3rd) soon to compare. Nose is powerful red wine vinegar tartness and a really pleasant sour cherry/wood component. Just a hint of funkiness. Flavor was hugely lactic sour on the first sip. After sitting and resting a bit, it mellowed and the cherry and earthiness and leather. Crisp, pretty dry finish. Liked it, and its certainly a well-constructed beer, though not my favorite from LA/PP.

Bottle: Poured a deep cloudy reddish color ale with a small bubbly head with minimal retention and not much lacing. Aroma of sour and tart notes with some cherries and light oak notes are all noticeable. Taste is close to a Flander red style beer with loads of oak and cherry notes and a well balanced tart finish. Balanced acidity is well appreciated while Brett is very hard to notice. Body is quite full with limited filtration and low carbonation. Well made though not s complex as some of the staple of the style such as Rodenbach.

05 Cuvee de Tomme @Tampa Wkly Gathering @tpd975s750ml bottle-pours an offwhite ring with cloudy brown color.  Aroma is sweet light/medium malt-caramel, apple, some spice.  Taste is sweet light/medium malt-caramel, apple, some spice, yeast.

75cl bottle thanks to Guy411.   Working my way through the LA sours, and a pattern emerges: they take a hefty base beer and decimate it with brett and whatever bacteria they are using.   Oh, and Im still 100% on carbonated bottles from Port/Lost Abbey, with this being my 28th rating for them, so there.   Brown-red color with a small tan head.   Lots of sour cherry in the aroma, with some barrel, light bourbon, and clean sour that isnt coming from the cherries.   The flavor has a rich malty base that is toppled by a dry cherry tartness.   Alcohol is present but light for a beer this big.   Then, sourness.   Lots of it, and that is impressive considering the base beer was a pretty malty quad.   Lots of cherry flavor, but there is so much going on that the balance seems about right.   Full bodied with a medium carbonation level and smooth texture.   A huge sour, but very well balanced.   Great beer.

2008 vintage. 350ml bottle thanks to Doubleo. Pours dark murky reddish brown with very small head. Aroma is strong with tart cherries, wood, brett, and some faint chocolate. Flavor is tart cherries, dark fruits, chocolate, brett, and wood. Has a real nice tartness. While there was little head the carbonation is near perfect for this beer. Palate is smooth and creamy. I like has it is sour up front but finishes with a smooth sweetness. Really nice brew. Alcohol is well hidden. Aging has probably helped mellow this brew. Cheers to Tomme and Doubleo who hooked me up with this awesome brew.

Bottle from hellbilly. Pours a very dark brown with dissipating head. Nose is strongly Brett. Acidic/vinegary. Sherry and cherries. Rich. Funky and dirty and earthy. On taste it is tart, lots of cherries and a rich molasses/roast tinge that lets you know what the base beer is. Very earthy and big. Full bodied, slick mouthfeel. Rich Rich Rich. This is a big beer that could benefit from a couple more years, I think. Still, Pretty big and a pleasure.

Dark brown with a tight beige head. Aroma is oak and cherries, earthy bretty and slightly "brown malty". Flavour is suprisingly tart and refreshing for the abv with strong brett, acidic candy (vingummi..) and lots of cherries. Very dry and easy to drink with a long aftertaste with notes of hai, cherry pits and wood.

2009 375 bottle
Very strong flavors and hints of sour.
Fruity aroma.  Pours very dark.  Considering the alcohol content it is very smooth.  Not a strong alcohol taste.

12th July 2008. Sour cherry beer. This really needs to be not over cold as a little warmth brings a mellowness to it. Sour cherries reasonably well balanced by woody tones. A dry beer. Okay but not quite the cherrry nirvana I was hoping for.

A somewhat flat looking 3 gets a nice bump to a four due to the good lacing.  Dark brown and murky pour.  Scent is sour cherry, quite appetizing.  A little bit of wood in the background, but not much else.  Taste is a little odd and difficult to describe.  The sour character from the scent is certainly there but this one goes through three or four transformations across the palate.  Sour first, wood second, sweet cherry and leather turning back into sour.  Very good.  This one is stopped from being an out of this world brew by a slightly lower than optimal carbonation level.

Dark, dark brown, with a beige head that quickly dissipates, leaving no head. Aroma is of sour cherries, funk, wood, plum, skin of peach. Flavour is massive, a fresh, puckering tangy sourness. Obvious cherry and fruit notes, chocolate, wood, a slight vanilla note, some alcohol, quite vinous, quite like a red wine. Some tobacco. Very juicy, surprisingly not especially dry. Carbonation is very sparse. A complex, surprising brew, not what I was expecting at all. Enjoyed it a lot.

Sample @ BBF Night of the Funk.  Pours a hazy brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is fruit, funk, and the oak/vanilla characteristic so well-known in barrel-aged beers like this.  Taste is sour cherry and dark fruit up front, with the brett, oak, and vanilla bringing it together at the back.  The beer is sublimely smooth throughout, a phenomenal drinking experience.

Bottle at the release of Flaming Fury.    Pours a clear still orange brown.  Acid, fruit, nice sour notes.  Nice and crisp carbonation with some plum and prune flavors.  Crisp acid and light funkiness.  Finishes long and crisp.

Bottle from Rollinhard. Pours dark brown, hazy with a thin tan head. Tart cherry, vinegar, bourbon barrel aroma. Taste is more of the same tart cherry, dark fruit, touches of bourbon barrel. Thicker than more sours and very drinkable, Awesome brew.

Bottle shared kindly by darkguardian. Pours a translucent brown with a creamy tan head. Cherry, malty caramel, tart with some light funk holding it all together. Opens up to wood, vanilla, very puckering. Tart, smooth and dry.

Big time love to the two people that sent this beer. Body is mainly reddish brown with damn little head. Aroma is  and ultra sour cherry smell with light dark fruit presence. Flavor is much of the same with a woody oaky flavor that skirts the edges.Very sour and VERY good.

Love to Matt for sharing!!! Body is a reddish brown with little head. Aromas are straight pie cherries. Flavor is tart cherries but has a very nice creaminess to it that adds intrigue and uniqueness. Lovely.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 2009 Lost Abbey. Picked up this bottle at Super Jr. Mart in San Diego during Comic Con. Almost no head. A little bit of carbonation in the mouth. No lacing. Aromas of Pino Noir and oak, wet horse blanket, stinky feet. Kind of mellow for a sour style ale, kind of light for a Belgian strong ale. I expected more bourbon aroma, but the blending and aging do produce a flavorful and unique beer experience. Flavors of hickory, red grapes, some very faint caramel, green pears, birch root, cherries, and fresh bread. Pucker inducing later mouthfeel.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2011 12.7 oz bottle thanks to Hopper.  pours a murky brown with a 1 finger off white head.  complex nose with tart cherries coming forward the most... followed by layers of light bourbon, oak, light vanilla and a touch of Brett.  nice round body with deep sour cherry notes, some acidity, light Brett funk, oak notes and a smooth vanilla character.  some alcohol heat on the finish with a mouth puckering sourness... the barrels shine through with a layer of cherry vanilla coating the tongue.

sample from the pitcher at GABF on 9/26/09... a murky brown pour with an off white head... big sour nose with a touch of cherry... pucker up on this one... medium body with a nutty sour feel... more funk over the mouth with some sour cherries... sour apple and a touch of raisin notes as well... big sour finish.  excellent stuff.

I like sours. This one is good. Aroma is great. High alcohol and wine like flavor is dominant. has a wild yeast flavor. If you like sours you must try it. The finish is incredible. I paid $33 for it. I may buy it again to keep and age for years. Drinks real nice. Quality brew. Not to sure it lived up to the hype though.
If you like this go to Grey Parrot Brewing in Washington and try the Altbier.

Bottle. Pours a brownish red, no head or any carbonation to speak of. Aroma is sour cherries, slight horseblanket and wood. Flavor is a great mix of tart cherries, wood, and hidden in the funk is a touch of vanilla. Reminded me alot of Supplication without the carbonation. Give it just a touch of carbonation and I think this would be a great one.

version 2009.
amazing aroma of funk, sour cherries, and oak. Incredible flavor of sour cherries, sour funk, and that great wet hay you would get from a world class lambic. Im super impressed with the beers ability to duplicate that amazing lambic sourness and funk. Incredible beer! in my opinion on par with a cantillon lamic.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2009 It pours a clear brownish color with an orange tint, there is a thin head to it that fades quick. The nose is so intense with a lot of sour funk and dark fruit, mainly black current. Im thankful for Drink4Satan for sharing this beer with me. As you sip on it there is a initial sour bite that attacks your taste buds like a mouthful of sour patch kids. This beer has a good balance malt, hops, and carbonation with the right amount of sour funk. Overall it has a nice sour apple and is a bit cider like in character.

Thanks to STLWill for this bomb tasty McFresh! The pour produces a clear ruby tinted cola colour with a short-lived wispy off-white head. The nose is rife with bold oak, vanilla, tart cherries, horseblanket and bretty yeast galore. The flavour is even more intense, with cider-like sweetness and acetic acid/brett yeast. The woody, vanilla character, along with sour cherry notes linger for some time, fading to a faint fruity sweetness. The alcohol is well hidden and the carbonation is gently and massaging, not quite prickly. Bomb tities!

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2011 4oz sample of 2008 bottle in exchange for a 24 bottle case of Bells Oracle hehe.  Huge thanks to drewbeerme!  Pours a viscous-looking/syrupy somewhat clear lightly glowing brown and red with a fine tan/brown head.  Aroma is of huge yogurt and cherries, light-brown sugar (opposed to dark brown sugar), seemingly virgin woodiness (not vanilla), almost cedary like fresh saw dust.  Flavor is quite boozy and tannic at first, plenty of yogurt, moldy dull cherries that are conversely very sharply tart on the back-end, cheesy, the tartness lasts without any degradation though the long aftertaste, finishes very soft and smooth.  Medium/full bodied, smooth light syrup texture, some hard-candy sweetness, almost no carbonation. Distinctly American.  Thanks Andrew!  8.4.8.5.16

[rerate 750ml 2009 bottle thanks to divinci]  Pours a wonderfully dark shinny fairly black with a fine fizzy white/cream colored fine froth.  Aroma is basically the same, full, somewhat rich, creamy, some of that yogurt is still there, much more acidic than last years, bright cherries, miles of woodiness, surprising balance, has a peppery sharpness, slightly more than mild acidity, much fuller and great balance, although the 2008 had great character in its own right.  Flavor follows aroma, fuller, rounder, moer complete, rich, bright cherries, light yogurt, very light, medium strong sharp tart aciditiy, much greater malt presence than the 2008, definitely more authentic Belgian, the malt characteristic is perhaps the greatist difference, provides a smooth rich silky base that is seemingly melded as part of the overaflavor, much much better, great tart sharp cherry zing in the finish.  amazingly smooth, full flavored and bodied.  Medium and slightly more than medium bodied, a hint creamy but mostly smooth, touch oily, with crisp appropriate carbonation.  Job well done. 8.4.9.5.18.  2010 bottle... totally different, flat, aroma is huge of cherries and black cherries, 8 or 9 here.  Flavor is quite good at the core, very big black cherries, reminds me of Small Animal, not the greatest vintage of Tomme, bit of bitterness.  Lacks carbonation and isnt as pretty as other pours.  9.4.8.4.17...

Bottle.  Pours black with almost no head.  Aroma is intoxicating, literally, of cherries, rum, raisins, dark chocolate, vanilla and sundry.  Really, my nose isnt developed enough to appreciate everything going on here.  The first taste is sour, then turning sweet with a taste of figs, dates, bourbon, and flat out booze.  A second taste really reveals the sourness and I wonder what Ive gotten myself into.  I really like this beer but feel that I cant properly appreciate it... too much happening at once.  The cherries are joined early on by a solid oak flavor, but then it is overwhelmed again by the sour overripe fruit flavors.  Good? For sure.  Up my alley?  Indeed.  Understood by me?  Not really...  and that makes me happy and sad at the same time.

Bottle from Sinners Group. Pours a dark brown with reddish highlights and thin head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of overripe cherries, rum soaked raisins, chocolate, light notes of bourbon, vanilla, oak, wood. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of rum-soaked raisins, figs, ripe dark fruit, caramel, light notes of bourbon, vanilla, smoke, wood, oak, hints of honey and bready yeast. Generally medium body with a sweet boozy goodness.

courtesy of ibrew2or3.
08 bottle. Pours dark brown, thin fizzy beige head with nice golden lacing.
Aroma had great notes of cherry puree with hints of bourbon in the back.
Flavor, barrel with warming abv, some light fruit tartness. Hints of malts and chocolate.
Barrel doesnt come too up front keeps some nice hints of candi sugar, caramel. Nice cherry notes with thick puree mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2011 750mL Lost Abbey guise 2009 ed into Orval trappist. Faint pop with the cork coming off. Pours a cloudy, deep ruby brown with no head like flat cherry Pepsi. Completely flat. Aroma is rich in sour cherries, tannins, sherry, oak-aged whiskey. Taste is close to a Flemish sour: mouth-puckering cherries, candi sugar but then shows notes of whiskey, oak chips, hints of soy sauce. A good amount of warming alcohol shows through. Reminds me a lot of De Dolle Oerbier Special Reserva but without the beauty and refinement. I feel there is a large dichotomy over this beer. One person who tasted this with me said it tasted like "muddy water," another said it looked and tasted like "flat Cherry Dr. Pepper." Sort of disappointment for rating #600 but it is certainly one of a kind though I would think twice about all the hype. A bourbon barrel-aged quadrupel/lambic is certainly a strange combo and is fascinating but perhaps this is too many disjointed flavors all combined at once. 8/24/2009 8/3/8/4/15=3.8750mL white label Pizza Port Solana Beach guise courtesy of ygtbsm94. Definitely better than the Black Label (which I lost my notes for). The pour is a muddy brune with really no head. Nose is fresh berries, balsamic vinegar, Flemish red notes like spicy oak and ganache. Taste is bright, lots of fresh raspberry, raspberry preserves dominate. Concord grape, spicy sourness, lactic sourness are all present with a dash of lemon tart in the finish. Rich, fresh, very beautiful. 1/11/2011 8/3/8/4/16=3.9

Thanks kiefdog for the share.  Pours dark brown with red highlights and an off-white head.  Nose is tart cherries, malt, must, cobweb, some vinegar, sugar, and some barrel.  Flavor is tart cherry burst up front, malt, unsweet raisins, chardonnay/ barrel tartness, and some brett.  Finishes off with more tart cherries.  Medium-bodied with lingering tart fruit.  Enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2013 08 bottle poured a rich ruby red color with little head to be found. aroma has nice funky sourness, dark fruit, cherry, barrel wood, brown sugar, raisin, and toffee. flavor really hits a nice sour level, tart dark cherry, brown sugar sweetness, dark fruits, medium acid, and light barrel wood. this one gets you puckering a bit and finishes with a nice dryness. really amazed at how rich this is but it remains clean. there is a fairly high sweetness here for a sour beer but it works and does not get in the way.

A 2008 Bottle. Emerica56, I thank you for inspiring me to rate again. Thanks John this one cheers to you. Pours a luscious dark red with burnt hues giving the brew a murky transparency. Creamy khaki head dances along the edge of the glass, disapating slow from the middle. Nose is delightful and tart. Cherry, cranberry, oak, vanilla, some brown sugar. Initial taste is a taste bud explosion. Intial tart cherry, rhine bitterness counter balancing with dark fruits, sweet malts, raisans, bourbon, vanilla. Hint of mollasses, caramel, cocoa mellows in the background into the finish. Acidity levels are perfect and not overwhelming at all. Medium body and silky mouthfeel. Refreshing, complex and well balanced. Alcohol is extremely well hidden. Palate duration is above average. One oustanding brew.

Have had this about 4 or 5 times, but now Im going to rate this 375mL 2008 bottle from weeheavysd, I believe.  Clear deep ruby with a 1/2 finger beige head, fading to a thick ring rather quickly.  Sour cherries and lactic acid up front with some raisins, brown sugar, bourbon and oak behind.  The flavor has a definite sour and sweet boozy side that are easily discernible, yet do blend together nicely as well.  Alcoholic heat in the back of the throat shows the strength of this beer.  There was also some light leather.  Sourness peaked around a 5 in the semi-dry finish.  Full body with light prickly carbonation.  Pretty good beer, though the 750 that was a few years old I enjoyed more (from badbeer, I think).
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Extremely dark brown pour with a minimal head. Aroma is absolutely ridiculous; lots of tart cherry and cranberry, vanilla, bourbon, raisin, fig, molasses- the mixture of sour and sweet and the malt complexity is phenomenal. Flavor is insane- initial hit is reminiscent of a classic belgian strong dark, with some awesome sweetness of plum, black cherry, and raisin. This aspect lasts briefly, and then unfolds into the middle and most lasting part of the flavor, which is a brilliant tart but still incredibly palatable and smooth sour cherry with bretty notes. At the finish, the sweetness comes back, but in a different incarnation from the beginning; here, it is more of an oaky, boozy, and sugary portrayal. Notes of caramelized sugar, molasses, and vanilla bourbon come through. The mouthfeel is also epic; extremely smooth and drinkable, but, like the flavor, is bold and complex- the tongue is never bored. This is an exquisite and unique specimen of beer. One of my all-time favorites.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2009 Bottle. Thanks to Rciesla for sharing. Brown pour with small carbonation. Sour cherry aroma and sweet dark fruits. Flavor is excellent: nice tartness,and cherry flavor; somewhere between a Belgian strong ale and a cherry sour. Nice brew.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2009 Thank you awaisanen for this delicious specimen. Dark brown pour with one finger vivacious tan head. Quick to dissipate, though the aroma surely does not. Aroma is tart at first- reminiscent of a fine kriek. Dark fruit comes through quite powerfully as well, with raisin most evident, and dark sugars such as maple syrup, toffee and caramel poking in more subtly. A slight vanilla bourbon quality is present throughout, which complements the other aromas quite fittingly and uniquely. Flavor is a swirling torrent of caramel, vanilla, tart cherry, unprocessed fresh cranberry, molasses and woody earthiness. Bourbon profile is present, but never distracting, providing a curious but well done complement to the dark sugar sweetness and ultimately the tart fruitiness and acidity. Palate is soft and velvety, providing a sticky but clean and highly quaffable texture. I think this one fell pseudo-victim to Lost Abbeys recent carbonation issues, but there was still a little left. I think it makes it even better than the carbonated one I had last week. One of the more unique beers Ive ever had- quite a masterpiece.   August  Re-Rate with craftycarl2 after 5 days of aging.

Stone Sourfest.  Ive wanted to sample this for about a year, and just never made the right connection at the right time.  Damn glad I finally got the hook up here.  Straight out goodness.  Rich and sweet.  Tart and cranberries.  Huge full mouth of flavor.  Simply great.

12 oz bottle thanks to Kegbear. Pours a murky brown with a small ring of off white.  Some legs on the sides of my  tulip glass. Aromas of cherry, vanilla, coriander ,vinegar,citrus and some oak. Nice carbonation and really nice sourness. Overall a wonderful beer.

2009 Bottle - Thanks JCB! - Pours a ruddy brown with no head...aroma is funky right off the bat, but not brett funky, more like chode funky...it gets better as it warms and becomes a rich, sour bouquet of cherries and cocoa, oak and dark fruit...flavour is full of lemon cherry pucker, vanilla oak phenols and a light delayed malt end note that creeps up...my obtuse human palate is far too ignorant to sense the carbonation, maybe if I was a mole or a shark or some other animal that more closely relies on its senses to live and thrive, but not mine...either way, very tasty stuff...

375 ml acquired via trade from goldtwins. My only 2008 bottle. Pours a murky dark brown, obvious rusty red notes with very small offwhite head that dies to a near nonexistant head, minimal lacing. Aromas are sour cherries, a bit of tartness of the bat, some sweet raisiny dark malts, but sour takes the front seat. Dark fruits, faint brown sugar. Initial is sour cherries, oaky dryness with faint vanilla, light dark fruits that preach tartness over sweetness. Very nice darker sour, flanders style that is subtle yet superbly tart. Alcohol well hidden as a touch of light funk, tart, oaky underlying meld almost perfectly. Decent carbonation, perfect body allow flavor and palate stickability to meld. Dark fruit sweetness and slight darker mellow malt sweetness incorporate into the back of the body. This is a very nice brew, finish leaves a tart and oaky lasting finish.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 2009 on tap at Stone Sour Fest 09. Murky dark brown. Heavy on dark fruits (raisins, figs, black cherry) and relatively light on the sour and funk. Sweet for a sour.  Looking forward to aging this for a few years, to see what develops. Solid as is. 
Sampled again February 2010, from a bottle this time. Touch more sour and funky than first tasting on draft.  Really nice beer, way easy to drink. Delicious! Re-rating change from 3.9 to 4.2.

750ml 2009 bottle. Bottle opens with light pop. Pours very dark brown with a small ring around the glass. Aroma is lightly sour, some fruit and a bit of tootsie roll. Flavor of vanilla, bourbon, caramel, tart cherries, and light bretty notes, maybe a bit of sourness. Some citrus, a bit of oak. Slick mouthfeel with just enough carbonation. Finishes tart. Absolutely stunning, exceptional ale.

Poured slightly flat out the bottle, dark black cherry color with very little head. Smells like 91 octane gas and cherries extremely faint alcohol on the nose. Mouth is full yet light and very dry. Taste is sour with faint chocolate. Sour even on the tip of the tongue. Delicious beer all around, dry and delicious. I will gladly purchase this bottle again...hopefully theres some left.

This beer had a slightly nutty / fruity aroma that hinted but didnt give anything away. The appearance was dark and semi translucent with a hint of sediment. The flavor was a WONDERFUL suprise. There is a strong nut flavor at the onset followed my a strong citrus lime middle with a fizzy punch.The after taste is a mix of citrus and nuts with a hint of raisin finishing with a slight vanilla. Overall it leaves the palate fairly neutral but exhausted. Each sip brings a cold sweat and sense of wonder.

375 bottle from lost abbey. Brought to Ians house for a beer tasting party. Pours a Roasted brown sugar chestnut color with a small brown head. Aroma of sweet cherries and sugar with a hint of wood. Taste of sugar and sour cherries. Pungent nice smooth flavor. Not much vinegar taste like most sours. I really enjoy this sour, probably the best one I have had.

750ml bomber, shared with two friends.  Pours dark magenta with almost no head.  Aroma is a complex blend of sour cherry, oak, cider vinegar, and fruit peel.  Palate is buttery, oily, and lightly carbonated, with a mouth-coating finish.  Primary flavor was bitter-sour, not sure which was more prominent.  Entry features tangy cherry, vinegar, lemon, and oak.  Mid-palate adds more bitter citrus peel in the mix, perhaps even some brett.  Whatever the components, the heft of this brew is certainly complex.  Cuvee finishes with acidity alongside smoke, dark cherry, and bitterness . . . a blend I found a bit on the sharp side.  Nonetheless, this is a wonderfully special offering, worthy of a deluxe occasion with fellow craft beer lovers.

375ml. 2009 Bottle. Simply amazing beer. Pours a deep purple with an average amount of foam. Virulent nose with notes of tart cherries, aged wood and balsamic vinegar. Flavor shows profiles of dark cherries, oak, granny smith apples and vintage red wine. Makes you pucker on the tongue, but not so much in the jowls like normal sours. Palate is moderately thin, but well carbonated. Finishes with a sharp, lively and acidic kick that lingers for a moment. Pretty much unbelievably good beer. Very few can match up with what might be Tommes finest. Share with those in the know.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2009 1. Sample from a Bottle at Logans Pre GABF Party, Denver 10/10/2007 (2004 Oak Aged Vintage)
Fruity woody and whisky aromas. Dark coloured fruity and strong in alcohol with a pleasant whisky finish.
2. From the Bottle at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 26/09/2009 (2009 Vintage)
Big sour aroma. Amber coloured very fruity and sour with a crisp and dry malt finish.

Bottles poured at NHC pro brewer night. Poured ruby brown. Nose is a tart cherry with notes of sweet fruit and fig. Flavor is out of this world! Big sour cherry, sweet sugary malts, figs, mild wood, some alcohol sweetness. Amazing.

375ml bottle. Beautiful beer. Foamy thick head thats not collapsing any time soon. Dark reddish-brown body that doesnt let much light through. Fantastic sour aroma. Not overly powerful, but clearly there. While the sourness may be clearly there in the aroma, it is nicely muted by the Oak aging. Additionally, the oak is not overpowering, just rounding out the sharp edges of the sour cherries. Tomme Arthur suggests aging his beers, but this one is pretty yummy right now!!

bottle from hophead22-  Thanks TIM.  pours a murky swampwater brown with a small head.  tart, but not in a mouthpuckering way.  notes of sour cherries, wood, sour grapes, oak, some vinegar  and earth.  pretty good and interesting for sure.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  could go for a little more.

This one is interesting...Not normally a HUGE fan of Belgian style beers, but this one might make me start trying new things... Pours a dark brown with reddish tints.  Short brown head with a wonderfully fruity aroma.  Its very sour, but only on the tip of the tongue and not on the sides of  your cheeks.  Taste is pretty amazing.  Has a very cherry-licious flavor.   A great beer!

Bottle Pours out a brown with red hights topped with a small tan head. Aroma was nice lots of cherries, oak, and sour apple. Tast lots going on here. You have the cherries, green apple, sour grapes, the wood, and some chocolate sweetness. WOW. A tast treat thanks to Toby.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2009 Bottle given to me from JCB in celebration of the birth of my daughter (welcome to the world, Isabel!).  Shared with my wonderful wife, who decided this beer was worth tossing out some breast milk.  Pours dark brown and hazy, with just a wisp of head upon its pour, but not much after that.  Smells lovely... sour cherries, dark cherries, oak, some vanilla, cocoa, bourbon, cognac, and brett notes.  Lots more of the cocoa coming out on the taste.  Similar to a fine Flanders red or an oud bruin, but dusted in cocoa powder, which gives a nice bitter contrast to the sourness of the cherries and wood.  Damn fine.
Sinners club. Brownish ale color. Intense taste of sour cherry and tart. Incredible flavor of cherry and brett. Man. This is an amazing sour red/brown.  Really enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2010 [Bottle] shared by STLWill. Pours hazy caramel with red highlights and a small beige head. Aroma is oaky, cherry, and some sharp acidity. Flavor has a hint of light bourbon, cherry, oak, and medium tartness.
Red brown with a small white head. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, cherries, vanilla, cognac and cabernet-sauvignon-like berries. Sweet and tart flavour of cherry and red wine, with American oak.

Big thanks to TimE for sharing this bottle with me.  Deep ruby/brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is full of oak, sour cherries, light vanilla, some spices, I think some chocolate, and just a bit of must.
